I would welcome an annual report from the Commission to the European Parliament. I pay tribute to the Commissioner in that once again the Commission tackled five Member States yesterday, because these Member States are not implementing, or not implementing properly, the licensing system nor the Interconnection Directive.

Mr President, I would also like to say something about the European emergency number 112, and this means venting some frustration. I already asked the Commission some questions about this a few months ago, and I was given a reply which left me none the wiser. We later asked some more questions, and hitherto have not received a reply. The 112 emergency number in the European Union was to become operational not later than 31 December 1996, pursuant to the Council Decision of 6 August 1991. But over the past few months, Mr President, it has turned out that, in practice, the emergency number has been leaving much to be desired. Many foreigners, for example, experience difficulties with 112 in a number of Member States, as the staff manning the emergency switchboard do not speak enough languages. How can I as a Dutchman make myself understood in Greece when I dial an emergency number? In addition, in some Member States the new number has been introduced alongside the old number. I would point out to you that in Belgium, for example, the police are still driving around and displaying the old emergency number. Belgacom issues lists which do not mention the 112 number. My response is, Mr President, that the parallel existence of two emergency numbers, a national and a European number, is not in keeping with the intention to have a single European emergency number. I also think this means that the symbolic function will be lost on our citizens. I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner which countries have not yet introduced the 112 emergency number? If the Commissioner does not have this factual information, would he see to it that an urgent inquiry is launched. My second question is, which steps, what action will the Commission take to ensure that the Member States meet their obligations resulting from this decision? What are his views on the idea that emergency switchboard staff in Member States should speak at least three of the most commonly‐spoken languages, in order to able to respond adequately when addressed by a hapless tourist in this respect?

In conclusion it remains for me to say that my group would be glad to agree with the common position supplemented by the amendments.

  Read (PSE). – Mr President, Mr van Velzen must be tired of hearing my congratulations. We spend our time congratulating each other late at night, with only the Commissioner to hear us. But nevertheless, it is the conclusion of another piece of the jigsaw in the telecommunications internal market. I congratulate him on it.

I have little to add to his own remarks except to say that I very much support his comments about the need to recognize the merging of the mobile and fixed point telecommunications markets. It is happening so fast that from the consumers' point of view, they really do not care too much whether they make their telephone call from a fixed point or a mobile, as long as they get through efficiently and cheaply and can make their calls. It seems to me entirely reasonable to be calling for number portability in the field of mobiles as quickly as possible. I very much hope that the Commission will be able to make some comment about that. We have the famous review coming in 1999 but we really cannot bundle everything into the review. We must make sure that where the market is merged we have regulations and a legislative framework to recognise that.

My second point is about something in the explanatory statement which the rapporteur has referred to, and that is the use of the 112 number. I should like to add an extra question to those of the rapporteur to Mr Bangemann. Is there any evidence that in certain countries, consumers using a mobile phone to make an emergency call, whether on the 112 number or any other, have to pay for that call? If you do not have that information I would be very grateful if you could let me have it in writing.

There needs to be a great deal more caution than perhaps the rapporteur's explanatory statement would suggest in introducing a change from national emergency numbers to the 112 number. The picture that the rapporteur paints is very worrying. But I perhaps would come to a different conclusion: that far from accelerating the process we need to take a great deal more time and trouble on a programme of public education to make sure that before we make a final and irrevocable move, consumers and citizens – particularly the elderly and those who are not so used to using the telephone – are absolutely sure what the emergency numbers are and what the procedures are for using those emergency numbers, both for fixed point telephones and mobile telephones.

So I am urging caution and would appreciate an answer to that particular question. Otherwise we support Mr van Velzen's report and commend it to you.

  Bangemann , Member of the Commission. – (DE) Mr President, what Mrs Read said is correct. We do not need to congratulate ourselves once again; we worked very well together. The rapporteur"s proposal for this is also acceptable to us.

I will merely go into the issues. As Mr van Velzen already said himself, if the amendment tabled by him is adopted it will lead to a situation where the Member States cannot fix the costs of carrier pre‐selection for those market participants who hitherto have not had any great market power. But he said that himself so we do not need to argue about it any further. We will then formulate it accordingly.

As far as the 112 number is concerned, the only country which has not yet implemented it is Greece. We will therefore continue our proceedings against Greece. However, we cannot continue our proceedings against the other Member States who did not originally do so as it is de facto no longer valid.

However, we do want to take Mrs Read"s comments very seriously. We must discuss with the regulation authorities and in a different way the Member States who are introducing this new 112 number the issue of advertising the number and publicizing it, as otherwise quite an odd situation arises, one in which there is a new number which is not known. The old number, which is known, can no longer be used. The two must go hand in hand but it can definitely be done.

The requirement that emergency operators should be in a position to work in at least three Community languages – well, in principle, as the satirical Radio Eriwan would reply – will be very difficult to implement in practice: if even the control towers at airports are not in a position to speak English and that is the only language that should be spoken there, then I have my doubts as to whether it would work immediately with three languages at these telephone exchanges. However, we can examine this; we can advertise it and see how far we get, as these numbers are used by people who are visiting or who just cannot speak the language of the particular country. I believe those were the questions I was to discuss. I hope that the final decision will soon follow.

  President . ‐Thank you, Commissioner Bangemann.

The debate is closed.

Voting will take place at noon tomorrow.


16. Labelling of certain foodstuffs produced from genetically modified organisms

  President . ‐The next item on the agenda is the report (A4‐0181/98) by Mr K. Collins, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection, on a draft Council regulation relating to the compulsory inclusion in the labelling of certain foodstuffs produced from genetically modified organisms of further information in addition to that specified in Directive 79/112/EEC (COM(98)0099 – C4‐0227/98‐98/0811(CNS)).

  Liese (PPE). – (DE) Mr President, it is a pity that the rapporteur is not there but I would like to discuss the position of the PPE group regarding the Collins report.

On Friday of this week we celebrate a memorable anniversary. The novel food regulation will have been in force for one year without the citizens of Europe experiencing any effects of this in practice. This is certainly due to the fact that we still do not have any legally binding rules of implementation and to the fact that the products which have already come onto the market in great style – genetically modified maize and genetically modified soya – were removed from the novel food regulation or the Commission"s interpretation did not hold these to be novel foods. At the time I was annoyed about this but I find it positive that it is now being proposed to label these foods too. Mr Bangemann, you have been much criticized in recent years in connection with this dossier. Here we have the opportunity to praise you for presenting this proposal and I believe that the proposal is, on the whole, not as bad as it is sometimes made out.

There are some points on which we could argue. On the whole, the PPE group is in favour of the proposals of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Protection but opinions can vary. We are of the opinion that a de minimis threshold should be set but that it should not be 5 %, as suggested by some, as this would mean that in principle we could not assume that there are any genetically modified foods. Everyone would be able to interpret it as they wished. Instead, much lower thresholds must be set and the Scientific Committee for Food must make suggestions here. A list of products which must not be labelled could be useful but I believe that none of the parties should become too involved in this argument as a compromise must be possible.

I personally am of the opinion that the Commission"s proposed “’may" provision’ is not so stupid; according to this proposal, if it is not known whether something contains genetically modified products this should be allowed to be labelled “may contain’. My main request to the Commission, but also indirectly to the Council of Ministers, is: please reach an agreement at last! Everyone must be willing to compromise. Those who hold extreme positions should make concessions. It simply cannot be possible that despite a regulation people must wait for rules of implementation. We need a clear decision so that industry and consumers know where they stand, and for this it is essential that everyone is willing to comprise.

  Lannoye (V). – (FR) Mr President, at this time I am sure you will be slightly more indulgent regarding speaking time as the rapporteur is undoubtedly busy eating asparagus which I hope has not been genetically modified. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is now a year, almost exactly to the day, since the novel food regulation came into force, at least in theory as it is completely ineffectual in practice. Today we are still discussing how to respond in practice to a major problem for the consumer: how do we label a novel food? What criteria should we use? What method of analysis is reliable? What should be done when GMOs are mixed with foods of the same type but are not modified? These are all questions to which there are no satisfactory answers today, at least not in the Commission"s proposals. The Commission is trying to break this deadlock by proposing a new regulation on labelling, which completes the 1979 directive and which applies to genetically modified soya and maize which had been on the market before the novel food regulation came into force.

What does the Commission propose? It opts for a system based on the detection of modified DNA or modified proteins in the final product delivered to the consumer. In concrete terms, this in fact signifies that approximately 50 % of modified foods will escape being labelled because modified proteins or DNA will be transformed or destroyed in the final product. This is not what the consumer wants. The consumer wants to know the origin of the product and wants to know if there has been any genetic engineering involved. On the contrary, it is what the manufacturer wants, as he is afraid that the consumer will reject his products. This is the problem which exists. What can be done about it? There is an alternative which the Commission has put forward. It involves analysing products in their original form at the beginning of the chain and guaranteeing, by means of a certificate of origin, products which have not been genetically modified, and of course monitoring the whole process through to the end product. We, the Green Group in the European Parliament, advocate this method.

We have tabled amendments to this effect and would like to add to this proposal that the suppliers of genetically modified products should accept responsibility for these analyses; it would be scandalous if those who guarantee non‐processed products were to be compelled to pay for the cost of the analyses.

  President . ‐Thank you, Mr Lannoye. The Chair will interpret the rules in a very indulgent way and agree that, as an emergency measure, our colleague, Mr Bowe, shall deputize for our rapporteur, Mr Collins. But this is strictly on the basis of a highly indulgent interpretation, and I would like to make the point that the Chair should be given plenty of notice of requests for deputies to speak in such circumstances. They should not be left until it is almost time to take a decision.

  Bowe (PSE), deputizing for the rapporteur. – Mr President, this proposal is extremely important in that it brings to what has in the last year been an extremely unclear and confused situation a degree of clarity which is long overdue. The issue of labelling genetically modified food is a crucial one in order to maintain public confidence and trust in the development of the biotechnological industry and in placing on the market biotechnological products.

The problem we have had is that with reference to particular products derived from GM soya and maize appeared on the market before the novel foods directive came into place. Consequently, there has been a legal vacuum and no really effective labelling procedure for them. The original Commission proposal, which is still under discussion in the Council, tries to address some of the problems relating to the labelling of genetically modified products. However, I have to say that if you examine the Commission proposal, it is rather like the curate's egg – good in parts.

In particular, I would take issue with the Commission proposal where it suggests that there should be a label ‚may contain’. It would seem to me that the ‚may contain’ label is one designed to create confusion, distrust and lack of confidence among the public, rather than trust. Consequently, Parliament has come forward with a proposal which will clarify the situation, ensure that products which contain an element of genetically modified produce that is identifiable by reasonable tests, at a reasonable price and of reasonable accuracy, are adequately labelled. This will engender some trust on the marketplace and hopefully a degree of sympathy and understanding within the population, which will encourage the continued production of genetically modified products and the biotechnology industry in general. One should not underestimate the importance of public trust and confidence in establishing a clear framework in which the biotechnology industry can develop. Legal frameworks are fine and are extremely important and legal stability and clarity are fine. But, in addition, you need public confidence if these products are to be marketed properly.

The proposal you have in front of you provides rules and regulations which are clear, understandable, based on sound science and provide the public with the information it requires to make an informed choice. It is quite clear that if we take these present rules and regulations and apply them to products in the marketplace, a substantial number of products in the ordinary supermarket will be labelled. I do not think we should have any fear or concern about that. We should be pleased that the public is given information, on the basis of which they can make a choice. Having been given that information and having a quiet confidence and trust in the product, I feel quite confident that in the case of some of the early products that have been placed on the marketplace – I refer, for example, to the genetically modified tomato paste which is now outselling ordinary tomato paste in the United Kingdom by 2 cans to 1 – you will see a slowly developed preference for genetically modified products amongst the population when they realize they are harmless, of good quality, dependable, reliable and that in no way reflect the will of a large biotechnological company seeking to make profit or a dangerous product which may threaten their health.

I think that the public, once it has had the labelled product before them and seen the benefits that derive from the use of genetically modified products in the marketplace, will think that our work tonight – of this happy few who are here tonight, almost this band of brothers – will be a stepping stone towards a much more logical, sane and sensible arrangement of the European marketplace. It is one in which biotechnological products are accepted as normal, sensible, healthy and acceptable, against the current view which treats them with suspicion, distrust and almost as the product of some strange unacceptable science.

I hope the Commission hears what we say and is prepared to modify its proposal because we know what the public thinks. I am telling you now, if you want to sell these products they need this labelling.

  Bangemann , Member of the Commission. – (DE) I do not wish to examine what Mr Liese mentioned once again. I would merely like to remind him that the novel food regulation was, after all, adopted in the form which Parliament accepted. At that time, when Parliament broke into songs of triumph, I said that it was somewhat premature because I did not consider the regulation to be very practical. I made no secret of my opinion. At the time I was criticized for this and now I am also being criticized for the fact that I warned you about it then! But perhaps that is the role of a Commissioner.

That brings me quite directly to the issue at hand today. Of course we also want to contribute to a solution and we assumed two basic requirements. Firstly, whichever criterion is selected, it should be based on scientific knowledge. We know that scientific knowledge advances; no scientific discovery will be valid in 10 or 20 years" time, but by dispensing completely with instruction by means of scientific knowledge we move to the realms of the arbitrary. We can do what we like; in our opinion it does not make any sense and it is in any case not constitutional. I cannot impose on anyone an obligation which I come up with out of the blue, so to speak.

Secondly, we should provide for a form of labelling which gives the consumer information which he can actually use, which means something to him. In the first issue we are now in agreement with the discussion in the Council. We will see when the time comes. The Council has finally decided to refer to scientific knowledge. In three issues it had a different opinion from ours, for example in the issue of a threshold, a minimum, and in the issue of a negative list. If we refer to scientific facts in these two issues this means that we cannot come to any decision at the moment. I will say that once again quite clearly. If in the end we are compelled by Parliament and the Council to do something like this, we simply have to do it. We do not wish to oppose it. I am very much prepared to say that it is simply the majority opinion.

In the third issue, that of the “may contain’, my opinion differs from that of Parliament. The “may contain’ has a whole range of advantages, mainly for the consumer but also for the small business, which is not in a position to do everything that is necessary to attach a “does not contain’ label. In order to ensure that no claims for damages are brought against them, all these people will label the products with “contains..’. You will then see, Mr Bowe, that even today approximately 60 % of processed food would have to be labelled, according to our calculations, and if we are to be on the safe side, perhaps 90 % or 100 % would have to be labelled “contains GMO’. This would then be a zero information for the consumer; if it is no longer possible to buy a GMO‐free product because manufacturers, for reasons of liability regulations, are more or less compelled to protect themselves from risk, there will no longer be any information for the consumer.

Once again, this is my position and I have represented the same position since the beginning. It is correct, Mr Liese, that I was told off for it. Now many people, particularly from among the Greens – perhaps not exactly the type of support one would wish for but anyhow, it is good if you support me in this issue – see how dangerous the actions of the majority are here. In this connection I would like to tell a story from Bavaria. Once, when a Bavarian Member of Parliament was reprimanded for having used his majority to trample a reasonable position to the ground, he said in his Bavarian dialect: it may be that the others are more reasonable, “but there are more of us’! So, there are more of you, and now we will see how we get on with the Council. Of course the Commission will not oppose a compromise but you cannot be annoyed with us if we say loud and clear that a solution under one set of circumstances or another is not practical or will not provide the consumer with the information he wants. This is the problem, not trust! There I share their opinion. The period of adjustment will certainly lead to the disappearance of the fear in which some of us now live. But there still remains the legitimate interest of the consumer. You know, does it or does it not contain GMO? We do not do justice to this interest. This is my opinion and, so far, also the opinion of the Commission.

  Lannoye (V). – (FR) Mr President, I have a query for the Commissioner. There must be an error or an inaccuracy in the draft regulation as it mentions products which had been on the market and labelled before the regulation came into force. The English word is “products’ but I assume it should in fact refer to previously existing stocks or supplies. It means that which is already in stock. But if the term used is “products’ this is ambiguous.

  Bangemann , Member of the Commission. – (DE) In my opinion no misunderstanding is possible here as the relative clause states clearly: “which were on the market before entry into force’. This means that it is either a stock or a product but it must have been on the market before entry into force. This is completely clear! Whether it was a stock or a product that is perhaps only in the production process is therefore irrelevant, it depends on the timing.

  Bowe (PSE), deputizing for the rapporteur. – Mr President, I have one short question for the Commissioner. If the Commission wants people to accept these products, why does it not give people what they want, which is simplicity and clarity. Get rid of ‚may contain’. Why do you want ‚may contain’? Just give people simplicity and clarity. Let them choose. Have some confidence in the people.

  President . ‐The debate is closed.

Voting will take place at 12.00 noon tomorrow.(1)

(The House rose at 11.38 p.m.)

ANNEX

I. Questions to the Council

 

Question No 14 by Carlos Carnero González (H−0422/98)

Subject: Future of the Agfa‐Gevaert production centre in Aranjuez (Spain)

In 1996 the management of AGFA‐GEVAERT gave an undertaking to the works council of the Aranjuez plant that current levels of activity would be maintained until the year 2000 but has still not specified any subsequent intention, despite the proximity of that date.

Does the Council take the view that the European Union and the governments of Spain, Belgium and Germany (countries in which the undertaking is based) should urge AGFA and, where appropriate, BAYER to do everything possible to guarantee future production in the Aranjuez centre at current levels of employment?

Can the Council urge AGFA to inform the works council of its intentions regarding the future of the plant after the year 2000 as soon as possible and to consult the works council, as the body representing workers, in accordance with the directives in force?

Answer

It would not be appropriate for the Council to take a position on what future levels of production should be in any particular factory, although Community legislation on the information and consultation of workers must of course be respected.

***

Question No 16 by Nuala Ahern (H−0428/98)

Subject: Integration of environmental policies with each of the European Union's policy responsibilities

What measures has the Presidency taken to integrate environmental policies with each of the European Union's policy responsibilities?

Answer

The UK has made the environment one of the main themes of its presidency. We have recognized the importance of integrating environmental concerns in all Community policy areas. This requirement is contained in Article 130r of the Treaty, and is strengthened by the inclusion of a new article in the Amsterdam Treaty which requires integration of environmental protection requirements into the Community's policies and activities.

One of our main priorities has been to integrate environmental concerns into the Community transport policy. We brought Transport and Environment Ministers together at the joint Informal Council in Chester in April for an initial discussion of the environmental problems faced in this area, to help prepare for formal discussions in a joint Council in June.

Environmental issues have also been integrated into the work of a number of other Councils. Michael Meacher, as Chair of the Environment Council, attended the Energy Council on 11 May for a debate on energy and the environment which produced conclusions focusing on, among other issues, climate change. The Fisheries Council in June will consider a report on follow‐up to the Bergen North Sea Ministerial Meeting on fisheries and the environment.

Much of the work of the Environment Council also affects other EU policy areas. For example, the Council has taken forward work on climate change in follow up to December's international agreement at Kyoto, on air pollution where measures to improve ambient air quality and to alleviate acid rain have been discussed, and on biodiversity where we hope for conclusions on a new Community strategy in June.

The European Conference held in London in March emphasized the importance of the environment in the EU enlargement process. This was followed by a lunchtime discussion of the environmental aspects of enlargement at the March Environment Council.

In addition to work in specific policy areas, the Commission is currently producing a general strategy for integrating the environment into all policy areas. The Luxembourg Summit in December 1997 called on the Commission to produce a strategy for integration in time for the next European Council in Cardiff. We have been liaising with the Commission and look forward to their strategy. When the UK Deputy Prime Minister addressed Parliament in February he stressed the importance of new integrative mechanisms to follow up the Commission's strategy. Since then we have discussed with the next three presidencies ways in which the strategy might be implemented in its early years.

Question No 17 by David Martin (H−0431/98)

Subject: Treatment of street children in Honduras

In the light of continuing reports of the ill‐treatment of street children in Honduras would the Council raise, with the Honduran Government, an incident on Christmas Day 1997 when Sandra Yamilet Gonzalez (16), Olman Fransisco Olivar (16) and Fanny Cerrato (16) were shot at and injured?

Answer

The matter has not been considered by the Council. However, the presidency has raised it with the Honduran Criminal Investigation Department and the Honduran Commission for Human Rights.

I understand that the third‐named teenager was not hit and that the first two are recovering from their injuries. But there is little information about the person who shot at them.

At its meetings with the countries of Central America, the EU regularly stresses the importance it attaches to respect for human rights and, in particular, to respect for the rights of the child.

On 11 March the Commission adopted a draft strategy on the New Transatlantic Marketplace and Commissioner Brittan has since been to the Untied States to present the plan.

Answer

The Commission's Communication on the ‚New Transatlantic Marketplace’ was discussed at the General Affairs Council of 27 April 1998. A number of Members of the Council expressed broad support, while others expressed specific concerns, and France reiterated its opposition. No mandate has therefore been given to the Commission to open negotiations.

Question No 19 by Richard Corbett (H−0443/98)

Subject: Gifts to Council members

Is it true that this gift was presented in view of the Council reversing the long‐standing decision to phase out duty free sales within the EU in 1999? Is it not time for the Council, which jointly exercises legislative power within the European Union, to introduce a register of its members' interests, on the model of that already introduced by the European Parliament, as well as a Code of Conduct, in order that such gifts should be prohibited or at least declared publicly?

Answer

The Council has not reversed any decision with regard to the phasing out of duty free within the EU in 1999.

Members of the Council of Ministers are all Ministers in their respective national governments. As such they are governed by their domestic rules regarding the declaration of outside interests.

Question No 20 by Richard Howitt (H−0444/98)

Subject: Towards an EU policy on indigenous peoples

On 5 June 1997, the Council of Ministers for Development Cooperation, after numerous resolutions of the EP and years of pressure from indigenous peoples and NGOs, adopted a resolution inviting the Commission to present a document on cooperation with and support for indigenous peoples. In March 1998, the Commission finalized a draft working document. In May, this document will be on the Development Council agenda. As the indigenous peoples of our world are disappearing and globalization and development put enormous pressure on their cultures and communities, it is of paramount importance that European development policies, where and when these affect indigenous peoples, are supportive of the identification of indigenous people's own priorities for development and are respectful of their cultures. Will the Council include this in its resolution as well as recommend that indigenous peoples be mentioned in cooperation agreements with countries where they live?

Answer

The Council can confirm that a paper on development policy in relation to indigenous peoples will be presented by the Commission to the Development Council on 18 May 1998.

The matter will then be considered in depth by the appropriate Council bodies with a view to the adoption of a policy resolution as soon as possible.

The Council agrees on the importance of this matter and the aspects mentioned by the honourable Parliamentarian will certainly be taken account of during the future discussions and in the resolution itself.

Question No 21 by Hugh McMahon (H−0447/98)

Subject: Council of Ministers agreement on an asbestos ban

In light of the agreement reached on a ban on asbestos during the April social affairs Council, can the Council inform the Parliament of the likely timetable for a ban on the use of asbestos in the European Union for industrial purposes?

Answer

In the light of the Commission Communication on the results of the assessment provided for in Council Directive 83/477/EEC, the Social Affairs Council at its session on 7 April 1998 adopted conclusions inviting the Commission to bring forward proposals for amending that Directive. It was considered that such proposals should, in particular:

‐ refocus protective measures on those most at risk;

‐ ensure that the risk assessment and information and training provisions of the Directive adequately reflect the differences between work where exposure is on the one hand intrinsic and on the other hand incidental to the work performed;

‐ emphasize that adequate maintenance, as well as the removal and disposal of asbestos under safe conditions, can play a role in preventing exposure;

‐ introduce further provisions in respect of work involving specific risks;

‐ revise the various concentration levels, exposure limits and measurement methods in the light of the latest scientific knowledge.

The Commission was also invited to review the risks arising from substitute fibres and to review existing provisions in the Member States in respect of the need to provide information on the presence of asbestos.

No agreement was reached on a possible ban on the use of asbestos. Although a majority of delegations supported a Minutes Statement to the effect that a ban was desirable, some delegations did not share this view.

Subject: Power of national courts to scrutinize EC acts

Does the Council concur with the Karlsruhe Federal Court and the Danish Supreme Court when they reserve the right to scrutinize provisions adopted by the EC for their compatibility with national constitutions and the powers transferred to the EC?

Answer

It is not for the Council to discuss or to comment upon the case law of national courts.

Question No 23 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0459/98)

Subject: EU registers of personal data

Various types of register are currently being compiled in the EU. Europol is to establish a register for tracking down wanted persons and for analysis purposes, and the Eurodac register exists for asylum seekers. When the Schengen Agreement formally becomes part of the EU Treaty, the SIS, Schengen and SIRENE registers will all become EU registers. Several of them may contain sensitive personal data.

What possibilities will there be for coordination between the various registers?

Are those responsible for the various registers, e.g. Europol and Sirene, going to be able to request information from each other?

Answer

During its discussions on the integration of the Schengen Acquis into the European Union, the Council has not discussed the possibilities for coordination between the various transborder police registers.

The question whether or not those responsible for the various registers are going to be able to request directly information from each other and, if so, under which conditions, is regulated in the documents setting up the various registers. It should however be noted that the national authorities can request information from several systems provided that they have access to those systems.

Question No 24 by Bernd Posselt (H−0462/98)

Subject: Sanctions against rump Yugoslavia

What sanctions has the Council imposed, or does it intend to impose, on the so‐called 'Federal Republic of Yugoslavia', particularly in view of the systematic genocide against the Kosovo Albanians and support for Serb nationalists in BosniaHerzegovina on the part of Belgrade?

Answer

The EU is fully committed to implementing the measures agreed by the Contact Group against the Serbian and FRY governments in response to the continuing violence in Kosovo and the failure of the Belgrade authorities to offer the Kosovar Albanians a genuine political process involving full and unconditional dialogue.

The EU agreed a Common Position on 19 March which included a reaffirmation of the existing EU arms embargo against the FRY; a ban on the supply of goods which might be used for internal repression or terrorism; a moratorium on government financed export credit support for FRY and Serbian Government officials directly responsible for the actions of the Serbian security forces in Kosovo. This was complemented by an implementing regulation on 27 April in respect of those areas covered by Community competence.

The EU has also agreed a Common Position on 7 May on implementing a freeze on the funds held overseas by the FRY and Serbian Governments; and officials are currently preparing a further Common Position on implementing a ban on new investment in Serbia.

We will continue to closely monitor the situations in Kosovo and the Republika Srpska, and maintain pressure on the Belgrade authorities to refrain from further violence in Kosovo and to urgently begin a process of dialogue.

Question No 25 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0464/98)

Subject: Forcible enlistment of young men by the dictatorship in Sudan

In an unprecedented 'sweep‐up' operation, the Islamic fundamentalist regime in Khartoum, Sudan, is press‐ganging young men aged 17‐19 into the army for unspecified periods of service and, after rudimentary training, sending them to military fronts to fight for the fundamentalists against Sudan opposition rebels and banning any communication with their families. This policy was confirmed on 2.4.1998 with the death of 100 trainee infantrymen who drowned in the River Nile or were shot when the commanders of their camp banned them from spending the Bayram holiday with their families and responded to their protests by opening fire. No investigation was ordered into these events, which the Sudanese authorities originally tried to conceal, and the bodies were buried in mass graves instead of being handed over to their families.

What pressure will the Council exert on the Sudanese dictatorship to put an end to the inhuman press‐ganging into the army of young men who should in fact be in school and how does it intend to investigate the events of 2.4.1998 to determine where responsibility for them lies?

Answer

The Council remains concerned at the reports of instances of illegal conscription by the Government of Sudan. The recent UNCHR resolution on the human rights situation in Sudan, co‐sponsored by the Presidency, expressed its deep concern at the violation of the rights of children. The Presidency's Embassy in Khartoum has already raised the events of 2 April 1998 with the Government of Sudan, and expressed its concern that there should be a full independent enquiry into the incident.

Question No 26 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0465/98)

Subject: Full and active participation of Cyprus in pre‐accession process

In the light of the conclusions of the Luxembourg Council Summit (12‐13 December 1997) which recognized Cyprus as one of the candidates for EU membership involved in the pre‐accession process, will the Council provide details of all the practical steps and measures it will take duly to prepare the Republic of Cyprus for its future membership of the European Union and of the strategy it will pursue in the coming weeks and months to achieve that objective as soon as possible?

Answer

When the EU opened accession negotiations with Cyprus on 31 March 1998, the Union confirmed its willingness to develop a specific pre‐accession strategy for Cyprus as defined in the Luxembourg European Council conclusions of December 1997. This strategy provides for:

‐ participation in certain targeted projects, in particular to boost judicial and administrative capacity and projects in the field of justice and home affairs;

‐ participation in certain Community programmes and agencies;

‐ use of technical assistance provided by TAIEX (Technical Assistance Information Exchange Office).

The Union has also made clear that Cyprus' accession should benefit all communities, including the Turkish Cypriot community. In that context, the Union's objective remains a bi‐communal, bi‐zonal federation on the basis of a comprehensive political settlement in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions. The European Union continues to encourage the involvement of Turkish Cypriot representatives in the EU accession process.

Question No 27 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0467/98)

Subject: Community programmes and Greek islets

INTERREG 2 is funding programmes aimed at protecting the natural environment of Greek islets. A sum of Drs. 400 million has already been approved to undertake minor infrastructure projects on 14 small Aegean islands up to the Year 2000, while some 50 regions of the Aegean have been designated environmentally important zones with a view to inclusion in the NATURA 2000 network. According to reliable sources the Commission has received letters and representations from a third country 'condemning' the above policies on the grounds that they involve regions whose sovereignty and ownership status is 'doubtful', and the Greek Government has submitted a memorandum on this matter to the Council.

Will the Council say whether this information is correct and whether a third country can be accorded the right, even indirectly, to 'judge' the legality and wisdom of Community decisions and polices which are, moreover, of a purely internal Community nature, and by exercising such 'judgment' to raise questions concerning the borders and sovereignty of EU Member States?

Answer

The Council is aware that the Permanent Representative of Turkey has approached the Commission in writing regarding the Community programmes and islets referred to by the honourable Member. The Greek Government briefed EU Foreign Affairs Ministers at the General Affairs Council in Luxembourg on 27 and 28 April 1998.

It seems that the projects co‐financed in the framework of the INTERREG II and NATURA 2000 Community programmes are not formally approved by the Commission on a case by case basis, but the Commission monitors that they meet the objectives and the criteria set out for these Community programmes.

The Council naturally regrets that the implementation of any such lawfully adopted Community instruments should become controversial between a Member State and a third country. The legality of the Community acts themselves may be reviewed only by the European Court of Justice. In its declaration of 15 July 1996 the Council underlined that disputes created by territorial claims should be submitted to the International Court of Justice. More recently, the Luxembourg European Council recalled that strengthening Turkey's links with the EU depended among other things on the settlement of disputes, in particular by legal process, including the ICJ.

Over the last few years groups of French farmers have attacked lorries carrying Spanish fruit and vegetables on their way to various EU countries. Last December the Court of Justice condemned the passivity of the French authorities because they have been unable to prevent these attacks.

The Internal Market Council will at its next session on 18 May 1998 hold an orientation debate on the issue which lies behind the question put by the honourable Member.

Question No 29 by Jan Bertens (H−0474/98)

Subject: Renewal of the EU Action Programme on light weaponry

In June 1997, the Council took an initial step towards combating the flood of illegal weapons by adopting the 'EU Action Programme for Preventing and Combating Illicit Trafficking in Conventional Arms'. That included a decision that the Action Programme would be reviewed within one year.

Can the President‐in‐Office of the Council say what progress has been made towards sharpening and reviewing the Action Programme?

Does the Council share my view that the Union must improve its export controls, partly by marking the weapons to be exported, as proposed by the Belgian Minister of Development Cooperation? What other specific measures can the Union take to help the developing countries control the flood of light weaponry?

Will the President‐in‐Office of the Council enter the control of arms exports on the agenda of the forthcoming G8 meeting? What will he propose at that meeting?

Question No 30 by Elisabeth Schroedter (H−0475/98)

Subject: EU Programme for Preventing and Combating Illicit Trafficking in Conventional Arms

In July 1997, the Council of Ministers reached agreement on an EU Programme for Preventing and Combating Illicit Trafficking in Conventional Arms. What funds have been used to date, or are earmarked for the future, for the implementation of that Programme?

Joint Answer

As the honourable Members know, the Council adopted the EU Programme for Preventing and Combating Illicit Trafficking in Conventional Arms on 26 June 1997.

Following the adoption of the EU programme, Member States have taken a number of initiatives in this field. These include the European Conference on trafficking in arms, which the UK hosted in February; the establishment by Belgium of a national inter‐ministerial coordination committee for combating illicit arms transfers; a UK‐funded seminar on illicit arms trafficking in Southern Africa, held in South Africa on 2 to 6 May; and the decision of Belgium to organize a colloquium on ‚sustainable disarmament for sustainable development’, which will take place in October 1998.

The presidency has proposed that assistance by the European Community and its Member States to other countries in preventing and combating illicit trafficking of arms should focus initially on the Southern African region. The purpose of the seminar on 4 to 6 May was to look at practical ways of tackling the problem in the sub‐region and identify projects for possible future funding by the European Community, Member States or other donors.

The EU Programme on Illicit Trafficking states that the European Community and its Member States are prepared, where appropriate, to make funds available in pursuit of the objectives of the programme. The initiatives mentioned above have been financed by individual Member States, but the possibility of future initiatives being funded from the Community budget remains open.

The Union has recently invited the Associated countries and the EFTA countries which are members of the EAA to align themselves with the EU Programme on Illicit Trafficking, with a view to concerting their activity in this area with that of Member States. The Union believes that the larger the number of European countries involved in common or coordinated initiatives, the more effective the implementation of the programme.

The competent Council bodies will soon begin the first annual review of the implementation of the programme.

The competent Council bodies are also discussing the Anglo‐French proposal for an EU Code of Conduct for arms exports which, once agreed, should set high common standards for legal arms exports from all Member States and contribute to convergence in the field of export controls.

The G8 agenda is a matter for G8 members. However, at the Birmingham Summit on 15 to 17 May, G8 Heads of State and Government will discuss international crime. Illicit arms trafficking may be taken up during their discussion.

Question No 31 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0476/98)

Subject: Prosecution and imprisonment of Kazakh labour movement leader, M. Ismailov

The leader of the Kazakhstan labour movement and deputy chairman of the Kazakhstan Popular Front, M. Ismailov, has been sentenced to one year in a correctional institution because, in a speech he gave on 7 November 1997, he bitterly criticized the political leadership and the President of Kazakhstan himself for the way in which the country is being governed. The sentencing of M. Ismailov has provoked a storm of protest from within the opposition parties and movements in Kazakhstan which are denouncing the sentence as premeditated political persecution of the consolidated opposition. They are also planning mass demonstrations in Alma Ata to protest at the government's manoeuvring and to demand the release of Mr Ismailov.

In view of the fact that Kazakhstan is associated with the EU in various forms, including a Joint Parliamentary Committee with the European Parliament, will the Council say what steps it will take to secure the immediate release of the leader of the Kazakhstan labour movement and to condemn acts of this kind which are contrary to the fundamental right to freedom of expression and in flagrant violation of any concept of democracy?

Answer

The Council is aware of the events surrounding the prosecution of Madel Ismailov and has been following the case closely. In cooperation with the OSCE, we will continue in our efforts to encourage the Kazakh authorities to allow freedom of speech and assembly. The Council is aware that this fundamental right is especially important in the build up to the elections in 2000. We will take every suitable opportunity to remind the Kazakh authorities of their international commitments in the human rights field.

Question No 32 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−0477/98)

Subject: Inaccuracy and unreliability of the proposal for reform of the COM in olive oil

Is the Council aware that the information and production figures on which the Commission has based its proposal for this sector are neither reliable nor sufficiently accurate?

Answer

The Commission has submitted proposals concerning a limited, transitional revision of the common organization of the market in olive oil, as the follow‐up to the debate held last year both in the Council and in the European Parliament on the ‚options paper’ presented by the Commission on the adaptation of the olive oil market organization.

The revision proposals are at present under examination by the Council with a view to their adoption in due course. In the framework of this examination all relevant aspects, including the question of the underlying information and figures, will be duly take into account.

The Commission proposal is based on Article 43 of the Treaty. Therefore, the European Parliament will provide its opinion on it. I am sure that all the aspects the honourable parliamentarian has addressed in her question will undergo an in‐depth analysis in this context.

When taking its formal decision, the Council will naturally take due account of the opinion of the European Parliament.

Answer

The Council fully supports the establishment of the International Criminal Court to try the most serious crimes and violations of humanitarian law of concern to the international community, including genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes.

Member States of the EU will play an active part in the Rome Diplomatic Conference to be held in June and July this year.

The presidency will deliver an EU statement on the opening day of the conference.

Question No 35 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0492/98)

Subject: Risk of general conflagration following decisions of the Contact Group for Kosovo

The Contact Group has decided to impose sanctions on Belgrade, including, initially, a freeze on Serb assets abroad and, subsequently, measures affecting investment. At the same time, the Contact Group noted the risk of the crisis in Kosovo spilling over the borders of the new Yugoslavia and assuming unforeseeable dimensions. This risk is intensified by the recent statements by the Albanian Prime Minister, Fatos Nano, who reportedly supports the armed struggle of the Albanian‐speaking population of Kosovo and has also called for the deployment of NATO troops in his country.

Does the Council not consider that unilaterally attributing responsibility to the new Yugoslavia is an inappropriate means of dealing with the crisis and considerably strengthens the extremists among the Albanian‐speaking population and their supporters whose aim is independence for Kosovo and the redrawing of the borders in the Balkans, fomenting further bloodshed in the region and beyond?

Answer

The Council is deeply concerned at the mounting violence in Kosovo. It has consistently and publicly condemned the excessive use of force by the Serbian security forces as well as the use of terrorism as a means of bringing about political change, and called on both sides to renounce violence and exercise maximum restraint.

It is fundamentally important to establish a meaningful dialogue between the parties without preconditions. The Council believes that the involvement of the international community is essential to establish a climate of confidence between the parties. It supports the efforts of the Contact Group in this area and welcomes the intention of Mr Gonzalez to arrange an early visit to Belgrade as representative of the OSCE and the EU.

The Council supports the approach of the Contact Group to Kosovo, which it regards as objective and balanced. The Contact Group stated on 29 April its clear wish to see the FRY integrated into the international community. However, President Milosevic has a personal responsibility to promote a peaceful settlement to the Kosovo issue. So far he has failed to meet key requirements set by the Contact Group.

The presidency raised personally with Prime Minister Nano the EU's concerns over his alleged comments. He stated that he had condemned terrorism in the same speech, and he remained committed to a peaceful resolution. Prime Minister Nano said he would welcome greater support from the international community in improving the security of the border with Kosovo.

Question No 36 by Mark Watts (H−0079/98)

Subject: Seizure of Jewish property

Significant items of Jewish property seized by the Nazis some fifty years ago are held by certain Member State governments who refuse to surrender them, even when the heirs to the Jewish owners demand their return.

What action will the Council take to end this injustice and encourage or ensure that the Member State governments concerned either return the goods or compensate the victims of Nazi confiscation?

Answer

If there is any property now held by Member States which had been confiscated by the Nazis, restitution or compensation for its confiscation would be a matter for the governments of the Member States concerned. It is not one in which the Council would have the power to act.

Question No 38 by Jens‐Peter Bonde (H−0342/98)

Subject: The Treaty of Amsterdam and the ending of existing border controls

Will the provisions of Article 14(2) of the EC Treaty (post‐Amsterdam consolidated version) relating to an area without internal frontiers in which the freedom of movement is ensured take effect directly after the Treaty of Amsterdam enters into force, or will individual Member States be able to maintain existing border controls?

Answer

II. Questions to the Commission

 

Question No 42 by Astrid Thors (H−0461/98)

Subject: Trade in human organs

The press has recently been focusing on the trade in organs, demand for which often outstrips supply. This shortage has resulted in an international trade in organs, the prospects of which are frightening and which has led to ethical and legal debates in several Member States. Those who donate their organs in return for payment often have no choice. The poor and the Untouchables in India and executed prisoners in China do not voluntarily donate their organs to the West. The organ shortage must be remedied on the basis of voluntary arrangements. The human body should be beyond the limits of the free market.

Has the Commission discussed the problem of trade in organs? What steps will it take to put a stop to those forms of the trade which do not fulfill basic ethical requirements, whether in the Member States or in the applicant countries?

Answer

The Commission is aware of reports in the media that the chronic shortage of organs has led to the development of trafficking in organs. Consideration of ethical issues and action in these matters are, however, for the Member States to deal with.

The Commission, however, follows up closely the work of international organizations competent in this field, such as the Council of Europe, and has supported cooperation between the Member States and the exchange of information on policies and programmes.

Furthermore, the European Group on Ethics in Science and New Technologies, which replaced the Group of Advisors on the Ethical implications of Biotechnology following a Commission decision of 16 December 1997, will deliver, during the course of 1998, an opinion on the ethical aspects of the functioning of Human Tissue Banks.

Finally, when the Amsterdam Treaty is ratified, the Commission will be able to explore the possibilities in this context under Article 152 which will replace the present Article 129 on public health. This new article contains specific references to measures on the safety of organs.

Question No 43 by José Barros Moura (H−0466/98/rev. 1)

Subject: Community funding for hydraulic works in Spain

Could the Commission say why it has persistently failed to give any explanation whatsoever for the confusing nature of its criteria regarding the conditions for funding and monitoring in respect of major hydraulic works in Spain (measure 6.1 – Hydraulic Scheme) and Portugal (Alqueva)?

With regard to the ERDF‐funded works in the Spanish part of the Guadiana basin, could the Commission say whether it sought to comply with any of the conditions imposed on the Portuguese authorities in respect of the River Alqueva?

Answer

The Commission regrets the fact that the information the Member has already received on the arrangements for and monitoring of Community cofinancing, both in the Guadiana basin in Spain and the vast Alqueva project in Portugal, has as yet been unable to meet his needs. It hopes to be able to clear up what seems to be a misunderstanding for him.

Although they are neighbours geographically, the vast Alqueva project and the hydraulic development work in the Guadiana basin are not comparable.

Firstly, that is a project which mobilizes Community funds of more than ECU 300 million. Secondly, the work carried out is fragmented and only requires Community cofinancing on a sporadic and incidental basis. Most of the development in the Guadiana basin is managed autonomously by the Spanish authorities, in the framework of their National Hydrological Plan which, in addition, has not as yet taken on its definitive form. Some parts of this work has, both in the past and currently, been able to benefit from ERDF cofinancing, insofar as they have been included in the Objective 1 operational programmes in Andalusia and formed part of the priority projects that the Spanish authorities retained.

The conditions for cofinancing and monitoring which have been applied to these Spanish programmes are those which govern each of the ERDF actions; they are applied in a uniform and regulated way with respect to all of the Member States.

The conditions which have been applied to the cofinancing of the Alqueva project follow on from the importance and global nature of this vast project, for which a certain number of specific elements stemming from its scale, its nature and its many implications have had to be taken into consideration.

The Commission confirms that there is no project in Spain which, in terms of its size and nature, can be likened or compared to the Alqueva project as regards the ERDF actions. The same is true of the Cohesion Fund, which in Spain has not financed any project which is comparable and on such a large scale in this field.

It must therefore be clear that the Commission has not treated Spain more favourably than Portugal in the matter raised by the Member, and it will supplement this with statistics on the implementation of hydraulic infrastructure measures in the Portuguese and Spanish programmes.

Question No 52 by Alexandros Alavanos (H−0439/98)

Subject: Olympic Airways

In a communication of June 1996 (OJ C 176, 19.6.1996, p.5) concerning restructuring aid granted to Olympic Airways, the Commission emphasizes that the 1994 economic survival plan has been 'correctly applied' and that OA has 'made significant efforts to return to profitability, ...substantially reduced its operating costs and increased productivity' and 'improved its commercial policy'. In April 1998 the Government acknowledged the failure of the 1994 restructuring plan and adopted a new programme which changed working conditions and working hours, reduced wage and salary levels and imposed a new three‐year wage and salary plan. Will the Commission say whether it had had at its disposal any evidence for the failure of the 1994 Programme, whether it had issued a warning to the Greek Government concerning the adoption of new restructuring measures and which commitments arising from the 1994 programme were not respected by the Greek Government and who is responsible for its failure?

Question No 53 by Mihail Papayannakis (H−0442/98)

Subject: Restructuring of Olympic Airways

How does the Commission rate prospects for the restructuring and development of Olympic Airways following the adoption of the new law on this matter by the Greek Government?

Question No 54 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0468/98)

Subject: Implementation of Olympic Airways restructuring plan

In 1994 the Greek Government and the Commission agreed on a three‐year (1995‐1997) restructuring plan for Olympic Airways which provided for the possibility of state aid to support its operations and the promotion of specific restructuring measures. However, the implementation of this plan has been subject to long delays, and there have been substantial departures from what was agreed on; as a result, the Greek Government has resorted to adopting a national law to regulate this matter. However, this law has been heavily criticized by all Greek political parties as well as the staff of Olympic Airways. Given these latest developments, can the Commission say whether it can detect any progress in the implementation of the 1994 restructuring plan and whether it intends to allow the Greek state to continue to subsidize Olympic Airways?

Joint answer

In 1994, the Commission authorized various measures of State aid granted by Greece to Olympic Airways(1) . This authorization was based on a comprehensive three‐year restructuring plan which was aimed at ensuring the return to viability of the company by 1997 and it was provided only after the Greek Government had formally accepted several conditions including the obligations:

* not to interfere unduly in the management of the company,

* not to grant the company any further aid in any form whatsoever,

* to give the company the status of a public limited company under ordinary law, and

* to bring the agreements between it and the company into line with Community law.

In the course of exercising its duty to examine progress with the restructuring plan, in April 1996, the Commission came to the conclusion that the Greek authorities had not fulfilled a number of its essential commitments and consequently the Commission reactivated the State aid procedure and blocked the aid measures that had not yet been granted(2) .

In December 1997, a preliminary report demonstrated that, despite some initial achievements, the implementation of the plan had lost momentum and that, as a consequence, the viability of the company was jeopardized. The Commission then informed the Greek authorities and Olympic Airways that a credible restructuring plan was needed together with measures designed to remedy the violations of the commitments already referred to.

This is the background to the plan recently adopted and based on modified working regulations which were passed by the Greek Parliament last month. The Commission welcomes this positive move. The Commission is now reviewing the new plan in order to establish whether it will allow the company to become viable within a reasonable time frame, without requiring any additional State aid. The Commission will also need to be satisfied about the effective implementation of the plan. Both elements are necessary to ensure that Olympic Airways will be able to participate actively in and benefit from the liberalized European air transport market.

Question No 55 by Hugh McMahon (H−0448/98)

Subject: Safety rules and standards for passenger ships

In light of the 2074th Council meeting on transport on 17 March 1998, can the Commission inform Parliament what the timescale will be for the implementation of legislation relating to safety rules and standards for passenger ships and what procedures will be established for international negotiations to harmonize rules on passenger ships making voyages in international waters?

Answer

In adopting the Directive on Safety Rules and Standards for Passenger ships on 17 March 1998, the Council confirmed the implementation date which it had agreed upon in its common position and Member States are therefore required to transpose the Directive by 1 July this year.

The procedures for international negotiations to harmonize rules on passenger ships engaged on international voyages are laid down in article 12 of the Directive. They provide that the Community shall submit a request to the International Maritime Organization to expedite its ongoing work to revise the SOLAS Regulations containing those issues which are left to the discretion of the administrations, to establish harmonized interpretations for these regulations, and to adopt amendments to the regulations accordingly.

This request will be made on the basis of the harmonized regulations laid down in Annex I to the Directive. Member States will be bound by article 12 to do their utmost to ensure that the IMO undertake the development of harmonized regulations without undue delay.

Question No 56 by Ursula Stenzel (H−0456/98)

Subject: Alpine transit

In question H−0294/98 to the Council, I specifically referred to the position of Parliament (resolution B4‐0029/98) and urged the Council to ensure that no EU Member State is placed in a less favourable situation than Switzerland. In its reply to this question the Council stressed that it was doing its utmost to find a suitable and durable solution which avoided diversion of traffic in the Alpine region.

Has the Commission taken account of Parliament's position and the importance of this issue for the Alpine region?

If so, why did the agreement reached on 23.1.1998 between the EU and Switzerland (Commissioner Kinnock for the EU, Mr Leuenberger for Switzerland) guarantee only Switzerland a safeguard clause? Such a clause would be of great importance, as it would permit adequate counter‐measures to be taken in the event of an unforeseen rise in diverted transit traffic over the coming years.

What, in the Commission's view, are the chances of the agreement, which the EU and Switzerland failed to conclude on 17.3.1998, being brought to a successful conclusion soon in the way outlined above?

Answer

One of the main objectives of the Community in the negotiations with Switzerland is to create a stable, efficient and sustainable policy regime for transport across the entire Alpine region so that existing traffic diversion is reduced and additional traffic diversion is avoided in the future. The Commission considers that the draft agreement it is negotiating with Switzerland properly meets this requirement and is consistent with the principles and purposes of Parliament's resolution.

The honourable Member is not correct in her assertion that only Switzerland would be guaranteed a safeguard clause in the package negotiated on 23 January. Both the Community and Switzerland would have a unilateral safeguard clause which means that in defined circumstances and subject to time limitations and charging ceilings, either could unilaterally increase road charges. In addition, the draft stipulates that, in specified circumstances – and only if both parties agree – safeguard measures may be taken at the request of one of the parties.

The Commission remains confident that the agreement can be concluded in the near future, provided that satisfactory progress can be made in the negotiations on non‐transport issues.

Question No 57 by Christoph Konrad (H−0494/98)

Subject: Flight, flying duty and rest times of flight crews

When will the Commission be following up its White Paper on the sectors and activities excluded from the Directive on working time by specific proposals for directives?

On what grounds is the Commission now proposing to regulate these sectors after all? What improvements does the Commission hope to gain from special sets of rules of this kind?

Does the Commission take the view that extending the working time Directive, 93/104/EEC(3) to mobile air transport workers (flight crews) may lead to distortions of competition?

How will the Commission rule out the possibility that amending the working times of aircraft crews on trans‐Atlantic flights will distort competition between Rome, Frankfurt and London?

Answer

The Commission is currently undertaking the second phase of consultation with the Social Partners on the sectors and activities excluded from the Working Time Directive and will submit specific proposals for some modes in the light of that consultation.

Although these sectors were excluded from the original Directive, the Commission has always made clear its intention to bring forward appropriate proposals. When there are some 140m workers covered by the provisions of the general Directive, there can be no convincing reason for not introducing comparable provisions for transport and other workers, especially when account is taken of the health and safety of the workers and of the safety of the public in general and passengers in particular.

The Commission also understands the differences in circumstances and needs in the various transport modes and has responded in the relevant White Paper with differentiated proposals to take proper account of that.

The Commission is currently working to produce a regulatory framework for flight and rest time requirements in civil aviation. The Commission is fully aware of the potential implications of such a framework for competition between Community carriers and between them and their main foreign counterparts. It is, therefore, working on developing provisions – based on operational practice and scientific knowledge – which would have the necessary flexibility to ensure that operations are both inherently safe and tailored to the network of each operator.

Question No 58 by Ioannis Theonas (H−0495/98)

Subject: Extension of current cabotage arrangements

Regulation 3577/92(4) concerning the liberalization of cabotage stipulates that the transitional period for Greece expires on 31 December 1998 for cruise services and on 31 December 2003 for coastal services. This regulation has created severe problems wherever it has been implemented, provoking strong reactions from workers in the sector and all the organizations involved. The impending full liberalization of cabotage in Greece, a sector of particular public interest, will undermine efforts to develop the Greek islands – outlying border regions of the EU, most of which are not easily accessible – and exacerbate their communication problems. Furthermore, under competitive conditions, profit will be the only motive for operating a service, contrary to any notion of social solidarity. Such a development will result in increased unemployment in a disadvantaged region and will intensify the trend towards depopulation and migration to towns on the mainland. Moreover, the security and defence of the islands will suffer a severe setback as internal shipping will no longer form part of the country's defence plan at a time when Turkey's territorial claims are aggravating relations between the two countries and causing justifiable concern.

Answer

Regulation 3577/92 was a delicately balanced agreement in Council and Greece was granted an additional five‐year exemption from implementation for two island cabotage sectors. The Commission is not planning to prolong the current regime for cabotage specified in the Regulation.

As required under the Regulation, the Commission has proposed an amendment of the Regulation as part of a wider policy initiative on the manning of regular passenger and ferry services between Community ports and that proposal was formally made last month.

It provides that, for vessels carrying out regular passenger and ferry services – including mixed passenger/cargo and scheduled cruise services – the host Member State may impose its rules relating to the proportion of Community nationals in the crew. In addition, where host States allow third country nationals to be employed on such services the proposal provides for such crew members to be treated as Community nationals for the purpose of terms and conditions of employment.

The new proposal aims to strike a fair balance between the need to implement the principle of freedom to provide services and the wish to protect the employment situation of Community seafarers in the labour intensive regular passenger ferry sector.

It should also be recalled that, under the Council Directive(5) on seafarer training, Member States may require that a certain percentage of the crew is able to speak the local language, thereby benefiting local employment.

Finally, Member States do, of course, have at their disposal the possibility of concluding public service contracts and imposing public service obligations where that is held to be necessary.

Question No 59 by Shaun Spiers (H−0375/98)

Subject: Residues in food stuffs

Is the Commission aware of the National Consumer Council's latest report – Farm Policies and Our Food: The Need for Change?

Will the Commission be coordinating and making publicly available the findings of surveillance on residues of veterinary medicines, pesticides and nitrates in foodstuffs?

Is the Commission developing a system for ensuring that maximum residue levels are not exceeded for pesticides and nitrates in food and drinking water?

Answer

The Commission is aware of the National Consumer Council's latest report ‚Farm Policies and our Food: The Need for Change’ and is currently examining the report in detail.

Council Directive 96/23/EC on measures to monitor certain substances and residues thereof in live animals and animal products requires Member States to implement every year from 1998 a residue monitoring plan for the detection of residues of veterinary drugs and contaminants, including pesticides. This surveillance aims to control compliance with maximum residue limits (MRLs) of veterinary drugs and pesticides fixed by Community legislation and to monitor the concentration of environmental contaminants. The Directive requires Member States to make public the outcome of the implementation of the plans. Moreover, each year from 1999 the Commission shall send Parliament and the Council a communication on the results of action taken in 1998 at regional, national or Community level.

Community legislation on the fixing of maximum levels for pesticide residues in cereals, animal products and fruit and vegetables (Directives 86/362/EEC, 86/363/EEC and 90/642/EEC all as most recently amended by Directive 97/41/EC) includes provisions on inspection and monitoring to ensure compliance with MRLs and publication of monitoring results. Member States are required to monitor pesticide residue levels to ensure compliance with MRLs fixed in Community legislation according to national and Commission coordinated plans and to send their results to the Commission annually. From 1999 the Commission will collate these reports and forward them to the standing committee on plant health for review and adoption of any necessary measures.

Controls of the levels of nitrates in lettuces and spinach are made by Member States under Commission Regulation (EC) No 194/97 of 31 January 1997 setting maximum levels for certain contaminants in foodstuffs.

Standards for drinking water are laid down in Council Directive 80/778/EEC relating to the quality of water intended for human consumption. This lays down maximum admissible concentrations (MAC) for pesticides and related products. For substances considered separately the MAC is 0.1 μg/litre. For the total concentration of substances the MAC is 0.5 μg/litre. For nitrate a MAC is fixed of 50 mg/litre and a guide level of 25 mg/l. The Directive is currently undergoing revision and the Council adopted a common position (EC) No 13/98 on 19 December 1997 in which the MACs laid down for pesticides and nitrates remain unchanged.

Question No 60 by Edgar Schiedermeier (H−0379/98)

Subject: Survey of town twinning arrangements by the Institute for European Partnerships and International Cooperation (IPZ)

I have heard that the Institute for European Partnerships and International Cooperation is currently conducting a survey of existing town twinning arrangements. Subject: LEADER II programme in Spain

Question No 63 by Joan Colom i Naval (H−0384/98)

Subject: Implementation rates for the LEADER programme in Spain for 1996 and 1997
