Question No 64 by Juan Colino Salamanca (H−0385/98)

Subject: LEADER II projects

Can the Commission ensure that all the funds not implemented for the LEADER II and local action group projects during the last two years will remain available if the projects are maintained?

Does the Commission consider that the LEADER initiative should be maintained during the next structural fund planning period and backed up by administrative streamlining to boost its effectiveness?

Joint Answer

The Commission is aware of the difficulties involved in the implementation of the LEADER II programmes, particularly in Spain. However, it must be pointed out that the Commission and the intermediary body responsible for the LEADER II global grants are working, withing the framework of the partnership, towards finding solutions to the problems which have arisen in the running of the Community initiative. In addition, significant progress has been achieved on questions relating to the eligibility of certain expenditure and to the financial management of LEADER II.

The Community appropriations initially granted to the various LEADER II regional programmes in Spain have all been allocated to the selected local action groups, through agreements signed by the intermediary body.

Nevertheless, implementation of the rural innovation projects presented by the local action groups is limited. The amount paid by the final recipients up to the end of 1996 varies from one programme to another but always represents less than 10 % of the total cost of the programmes. The Commission still does not have the data relating to the implementation of programmes in 1997.

The Commission is aware of the Member States" budgetary difficulties due, in particular, to the need to respect convergence plans, and in this framework it is easy to understand the difficulties encountered in trying to guarantee the national public contributions provided for in the LEADER II programmes.

In this connection, we should recall the possibility provided for by the Structural Funds regulations, under certain conditions, of modifying, if need be, the programmes" financial plans. This modification must be adopted by the competent monitoring committee and approved by the Commission. To achieve this, an agreement is needed between the different members of the monitoring committee.

Moreover, it must be pointed out that the payment of Community credits set aside for the LEADER II programmes is linked to the respect of the provisions established in the decisions of approval and particularly the payment of the expected national public contributions, which will have to be guaranteed when closing the programme.

The LEADER II programmes are managed with the flexibility allowed by the provisions which apply to the Structural Funds. Thus, the changes to the programmes have been adopted with a view to transferring the unused Community credits from the 1995 and 1996 financial years to subsequent years and to bringing the contributions of the various operators involved in cofinancing (the Community, private and national public administrations) more in line with the actual possibilities.

In Agenda 2000 and the proposal for a regulation laying down general provisions on the Structural Funds, the Commission proposed launching a Community initiative on rural development for the period 2000‐2006.

In this respect, the Commission proposed that this initiative should be cofinanced solely by EAGGF‐Orientation, and to this end the extension of the field of application defined in the specific regulation on EAGGF is planned. If this proposal is approved, the running of the new initiative will be markedly simplified and, consequently, its effectiveness will increase.

Question No 65 by Ulla Sandbæk (H−0387/98)

Subject: Pesticides in drinking water

Uncontaminated groundwater is very important in Denmark, as groundwater is the source of 98 % of the country's drinking water.

Can a Member State which finds that groundwater concentrations of a given active substance exceed the limit values laid down by the EU drinking water directive prohibit the active substance concerned even though it is included on the Community's positive list (Annex I to Directive 91/414/EEC)(6) ?

Answer

A Member State has the right to withdraw the authorizations or impose specific restrictions on the use of plant protection products containing an active substance listed in Annex 1 of Directive 91/414/EEC(7) according to the provisions laid down in articles 4(5) and 4(6) thereof.

The ‚Uniform Principles’ (Annex 6 of Directive 91/414/EEC) excludes authorization of plant protection products which under the conditions of use laid down in this authorization will lead to concentrations in groundwater above a limit value of maximum 0.1 μg/l.

The Drinking Water Directive(8) sets the quality standards that all water intended for human consumption, other than mineral or medicinal products, should comply with. The appropriate choice of water source, water treatment and water supply remains within the competence of Member States provided, of course, that requirements set out in other pieces of legislation are respected.

Question No 66 by James Nicholson (H−0391/98)

Subject: Disparity between the pound sterling and the Republic of Ireland punt

Will the Commission investigate the disadvantageous trading position being faced by Northern Ireland traders at present as a result of the serious disparity between the pound sterling and the Republic of Ireland punt and will the Commission give a view on when the present position can be alleviated and whether it will act to ensure equal and fair trading between both jurisdictions?

Answer

Since its exit from the exchange rate mechanism (ERM) in September 1992, sterling has been a freely floating currency. After depreciating between 1992 and 1995, sterling subsequently appreciated. In the past nineteen months, underpinned by the strength of the UK economy, sterling has appreciated considerably against the currencies of its trading partners. Over this period, it has risen by 32 % against core European currencies. At the same time, sterling's strength, together with the greater relative stability exhibited by the Irish pound, has seen the currency rise to 1.21 Irish pounds. However, the present sterling's exchange rate is the outcome of the free operation of market forces in the context of the strong economic fundamentals of the UK economy and the monetary policy approach pursued by the UK authorities.

As with any currency, the prolonged appreciation of sterling has led to a fall in the UK's exports, an increase in its imports and a worsening of the trade balance vis‐à‐vis its main trading partners. The Commission understands the difficulties by the UK traders in view of the strength of sterling. The Commission will as always remain vigilant in ensuring that developments in Member States are in line with the principle of an open market economy with free competition, as required under the EC Treaty.

The EC Treaty mentions sustainable non‐inflationary growth and a high level of employment among the common final objectives of the Member States. However, the choice of a macro‐economic policy mix to achieve these objectives is the responsibility of the Member States themselves, in particular for the UK, which has an opt‐out from participation in EMU.

***

Question No 67 by Alan Gillis (H−0396/98)

Subject: Money laundering

Given the illegal activities of non‐resident registered companies in Ireland what action does the Commission intend to take within the context of European anti‐drug policies to persuade the Irish Government to close these companies which the government has admitted are involved in money laundering activities?

Answer

The Commission is not in possession of any specific information relating to criminal activities carried on by Irish‐registered non‐resident companies.

The Commission is aware that earlier this year the Deputy Prime Minister of Ireland was quoted in the press as expressing concern that a number of non‐resident companies registered in Ireland, particularly from Eastern Europe, were being used to launder money in Ireland.

The Commission is informed by the Irish authorities that two groups were set up in 1997 to look into this matter. An Inter Agency/Departmental Working Group was set up by the Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, while another group was set up in the Irish Financial Services Centre.

Arising from the work of these groups proposals in three specific areas are currently under consideration by the Government. These areas are company law measures, taxation measures and the designation of company formation agents under the money laundering provisions of the Criminal Justice Act, 1994. While these proposals are still under review, the Government has repeated its commitment to finding a solution to the problem posed by certain Irish‐registered non‐resident companies as a matter of urgency.

Given this commitment on the part of the Irish authorities, and the fact that matters of criminal law in general are not matters of Community competence, the Commission does not believe that it can usefully intervene in this particular case.

At the same time and as part of its current review of a number of vulnerable professions in the context of work to extent and update the 1991 anti‐money laundering directive(9) , the Commission is actively considering proposing that company formation agents by brought within the directive's scope.

Question No 68 by Mair Morgan (H−0398/98)

Subject: Auto Oil Directive

Is the Commission aware of the substantial costs that will have to be incurred by oil refineries to enable them to comply with the Auto Oil Directive? Are there any grants or funding available to assist in these expensive conversions?

Answer

The Commission is very aware of the economic aspect of these legislative proposals aimed at improving the quality of the environment and it wants to assess it in relation to the effective reductions of polluting emissions. That is why the Auto Oil programme proposed improving the specifications linked to the quality of fuels by basing itself on the results of very comprehensive studies on the cost‐effectiveness criterion.

The Commission also presents very precise details of the costs involved in its COM(96)248 document.

The Community"s policy in the field of the environment is based, in particular, on the principle that the polluter should pay (Article 130r of the EC Treaty) and as such does not therefore provide for any specific funding.

However, for all that the projects are linked to the improvement of the environment and economic development and are located in eligible zones, they could benefit from Community funding in terms of structural policy or loans from the European Investment Bank.

Question No 69 by Vassilis Ephremidis (H−0399/98)

Subject: Tobacco growers penalized for tobacco merchants' wrongdoings

Commission Decision No 11543 of 12 March 1998 reducing by 20 % the premiums paid to 5 120 growers of 'basma' tobacco entails a loss of Drs 245 000 per grower and a total of Drs 1 250 million for the prefecture of Serres as a whole with disastrous consequences for producers' incomes and the economic and social balance in the region. As a result of blackmail by the tobacco merchants, the contracts for the 1997 crop were not signed by the appointed deadlines and penalties were then imposed on the growers – who were demanding compliance with the terms of their contracts – rather than the merchants who were in breach of their contractual obligations.

What measures will the Commission take to annul this unjust and unacceptable decision since sole responsibility for the failure to sign the contracts in due time demonstrably lies with the tobacco merchants who had not complied with their contracts and bought the tobacco by the market deadline in an attempt to blackmail the growers into selling their tobacco at lower prices than those stipulated in the contracts? What measures will it also take to protect growers as a whole from the irresponsibility of the middlemen and merchants who ruthlessly exploit them and make huge profits from their hard work?

Answer

It appears from the information provided by the Greek authorities that the registration of the cultivation contracts took place after the deadline. The registration of these contracts is an obligatory condition for the payment of premiums to the producers. However, the processing companies had filed the cultivation contracts, which have not been registered because of the lack of signatures of the producer groups.

Therefore, the EOK asked the Commission to find a solution to this situation, given that the producers used the refusal to sign the contracts for the 1997 crop, as a last resource, in order to obtain the payment by certain processors of the premium due for the tobacco from the previous crop.

After receiving the supplementary information on the respect of the regulations concerning the controls carried out by the Member State, the Commission decided not to set aside the payments of the premiums for these producers. Nevertheless, Regulation No 3478/92/EEC from the Commission provides for a 20 % reduction in premiums if the time limit for the signature or the return of the contract is exceeded. This reduction applies regardless of whether or not the producers are responsible for exceeding the deadline, except in the case of force majeur , and it has been applied by the Commission in the individual case.

Following this experience, the producers will have to protect themselves by avoiding the processors who are not capable of guaranteeing that their rights will be respected.

Question No 70 by Ian White (H−0401/98)

Subject: Retirement ages

Is a retirement age for men of 65 years, compared to a retirement age for women of 60 years in the United Kingdom, compatible with the European Union's commitment to gender equality?

What legislative proposals are being considered to remedy this?

Answer

Directive 79/7/EEC of 19 December 1978 on progressive implementation of the principle of equal treatment for women and men in matters on social security permits Member States to maintain different retirement ages for women and men, if Member States so wish. The Commission has tabled a proposal as far back as 1987 to modify this Directive, dealing among other things with equality of treatment on retirement ages, but no real progress was made in the Council, despite favourable opinions of the European Parliament and the Economic and Social Committee.

The Commission has stated its intention to draw up a new proposal for a Council Directive completing existing Community law in the area of equal treatment between women and men in social security, which will fully reflect the commitment to gender equality, and the case law of the Court. This proposal will replace the pending proposal of 1987.

It is understood that the United Kingdom authorities envisage that equalisation of retirement ages will be implemented between the year 2010 and 2020.

Question No 71 by Alfred Lomas (H−0403/98)

Subject: Television trailers of pornographic films shown in a hotel in Spain

Complaints have been made about a hotel in Spain that showed trailers with scenes from pornographic films on television without warning which were seen by young children. Will the Commission take steps to protect children from such practices?

Answer

The “Television sans frontières’(10) directive determines the Community regulatory framework on the pursuit of television broadcasting activities. In Article 22 it provides a complete range of measures concerning the protection of minors.

However, the films shown in hotel rooms can escape the provisions of the directive where they do not come under the heading of television broadcasts but under the heading of a programme made available to customers via electric means in a closed video circuit.

In fact, hotels generally have television receivers in their bedrooms which supply the broadcasting services. In this case, the programmes (films, film extracts, trailers) from the broadcasting service of a Member State must respect the directive"s regulation as well as all of the criteria set out in Article 22.

However, hotels often also offer an internal viewing circuit for closed circuit use. If the films or videos are shown within the hotel in this way, they do not come under broadcasting and if that is the case, only the national legislation in force applies.

Question No 72 by Klaus‐Heiner Lehne (H−0404/98)

Subject: Accession of Poland

Has the Commission studied the issues that will be raised by the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad when Poland accedes to the European Union?

Answer

The European Commission is fully aware of the issues involved in Poland's relations with neighbouring regions, including Kaliningrad, in the pre‐accession context. The Commission's opinion on Poland's application for Community membership noted that Poland is playing a constructive role in improving relations with neighbouring countries and that all Polish state frontiers are regulated by treaty arrangements.

In Poland's Accession Partnership the development of more effective border management and control systems for the whole of Poland's frontier is a short term priority, whose implementation should begin in 1998.

The Polish Government has underlined that the continuous improvement of political, economic and trade relations with Russia remains a strategic priority of Polish foreign policy. The existing agreement between Poland and Russia dates back to the 1970s and does not contain arrangements on re‐admission. Increased attention and efforts are required with regard to the oblast of Kaliningrad to ensure a smooth transition towards Community membership and good neighbourly relations.

Question No 73 by Anna Terrón i Cusí (H−0406/98)

Subject: Training needs in the textile sector

The Commission communication on measures to improve the competitiveness of the European textile and clothing industry outlines a series of measures drawn from recommendations by management and labour for the period 1997‐2000, forming a plan of action for the sector and including inter alia training measures for workers.

Is the Commission aware that women working in the textile and clothing industry need to have access to improved training and skills if they are to keep their jobs or take up jobs created by the use of new technologies?

Does the Commission plan to take any special initiatives as part of the reform of the Structural Funds, bearing in mind the regional concentration of this industry and the large number of women it employs?

Answer

With regard to the reform of the Structural Funds, the Commission believes that the proposed Regulations provide a clear basis for addressing such priorities.

First of all, the strengthened provisions regarding equality for women and men in the labour market – and the planning and monitoring mechanisms which are part of them – will, if adopted, introduce a clear framework for tackling all forms of vertical and horizontal segregation within the labour market. Secondly, within the European Social Fund, the retention of the political priority given to industrial and technological change and its effects on employment means that, if the draft Regulations are adopted, Member States will be required to make priority provision in this field in all programmes.

The specific priority given to the textile sector – and to female workers within it – will be a function of the needs identified in the ex ante evaluations and the financial and programming priorities agree between the Commission and the Member States within the specific interventions for the regions concerned.

Question No 74 by Manuela Frutos Gama (H−0407/98)

Subject: Green Paper on clandestine working

The Commission's communication on a plan of action to increase the competitiveness of the European textile and clothing industry includes, amongst other measures that have been or are being adopted at European level, the production of a Green Paper as recommended by the social partners on clandestine working in these two industrial sectors.

Can the Commission say what stage has been reached in the preparation of this Green Paper, and whether there have been any conclusions that can be vouchsafed to us? Has the Commission included the gender variable in the statistics used for this study?

On the same subject, has the Commission considered the option of investigating not only clandestine working but also nontypical employment, including the self‐employed, in the two sectors, and its pattern of development in the various regions of the European Union?

Answer

The Commission approved a Communication on Undeclared Work on 7 April, COM (98)219. This paper aims to launch a debate on the causes of undeclared work and the policy options for combatting it. It suggests that there is, firstly, a need to identify correctly the causes and extent of the problem, and, secondly, to regard combating undeclared work as part of the overall employment strategy.

Undeclared work i.e. lawful paid activity which is supposed to be declared but is not, is a problem that is common to all Member States. The extent of undeclared work is by definition difficult to measure but available studies suggest 3 groups of countries: those where it represents 5 % of the GDP, another group where it is estimated at about 20 %; and countries halfway between these extremes.

The age and gender of undeclared workers depend to a large extent on the sectors affected and it appears that women do not form the majority of undeclared workers. While most of the second or multiple job holders would be men, women involved in undeclared work would typically be officially inactive. This has negative consequences where their pension rights depend exclusively on their partner, rather than on their own work.

The reason for not declaring work will vary from one Member State to another but the main reason is economic – increased earnings and tax avoidance at the same time. Tackling it effectively will require an appropriate policy‐mix, which will inevitably vary from one Member State to another, but will draw on two basic approaches:

‐ awareness‐raising and enforcement campaigns to clamp down on undeclared work, and

‐ promoting labour market flexibility, adaptation of legislation and reducing administrative burdens to encourage such work into the open.

The Commission hopes and expects that the Member States, Community institutions and social partners will participate vigorously in this debate. An increased awareness of the causes and extent of undeclared work, the identification of best practices in combating it and the possibility of co‐ordinated Community action should be considered in this context.

With regard to non‐standard employment, the Social Affairs Council recently adopted a Directive which transposed the framework agreement on part‐time work concluded between UNIC, CEEP and the ETUC into Community law. Concerning other flexible forms of work, the European social partners have recently agreed to open the relevant negotiations on fixed‐term work. The Commission hopes that these negotiations could lead to an agreement at the European level. Finally, following the adoption of the employment guidelines, the Commission is looking closely at the legal and administrative obstacles in Member States for taking up activities as a self‐employed.

Question No 75 by Francisca Sauquillo Pérez del Arco (H−0408/98)

Subject: New qualifications in the clothing industry

It appears from the Commission's communication on a plan of action to increase the competitiveness of the European textile and clothing industry that in 1995 the Commission had completed an extensive study on the requirements for new qualifications in the clothing industry, and would be carrying out a similar one on the textile industry in the future.

Can the Commission say what are the main conclusions of this study, and to what extent they reflect the training needs of the large female workforce employed in the two sectors?

Has the Commission made plans to include these needs in specific measures, bearing in mind that in some European regions women represent up to 75 % of the workforce employed in the textile and clothing industries?

Question No 76 by Ludivina García Arias (H−0409/98)

Subject: Women in the textile industry

The past few years have seen a significant rise in the importance of women to the economy and employment in the Community. However, it needs to be borne in mind that the presence of women still varies a good deal in the industrial sectors, fluctuating from less than about 10 % in the fishing industry to about 75 % in industries such as textiles.

In its communication on a plan of action to increase the competitiveness of the European textile and clothing industry the Commission notes that more than a quarter of jobs in the latter industry were lost between 1990 and 1996, and points out that such losses were concentrated in certain regions, as a result of completion of the single market.

Could the Commission say which regions were most affected by these job losses, and whether the female workforce was affected more than men? If so, what in the Commission's view were the causes and what means should be used to counteract this unintended effect?

Joint Answer

The clothing and textiles sector is characterized by a high density of manpower of which women make up a large percentage, a percentage which rises to more than 70 % in the clothing sector. These jobs are at times concentrated in agricultural regions and the level of qualifications is low.

The loss of jobs in this sector affects, in particular, the regions of the Community where production has been directed towards low‐end products. This production rests on the low level of wages and qualifications of the workers involved which find themselves in direct competition with the low‐wage countries. The female workforce is therefore more seriously affected by the competition of third countries.

The study carried out by the Commission in 1994 on the requirements in terms of qualifications concentrated on the clothing sector. A study on the textiles sector is in the process of being completed. According to the conclusions of this study, in order to improve its competitiveness vis‐à‐vis low‐wage countries, in Europe the sector has developed a strategy based on the improvement of the added value, flexibility and the effective and rapid response to the needs of a globalized market where distribution plays a crucial role. This has led the sector to make increasing use of new technologies.

Furthermore, the study notes that, in this sector, there are still certain inflexibilities in terms of investment in the field of professional training. The reasons for this attitude are linked to the low level of pay in the sector and its lack of attraction as well as to the lack of professional motivations due to the segmentation of the production chain.

The new necessary qualifications involve the use of computers, an increased knowledge of the markets and versatility. These new qualifications can promote the situation of women in this sector through the reconciliation of professional elements and family life (for example, teleworking, flexible working hours, etcetera).

The Commission is convinced of the need and urgency to support all actions involving professional training, particularly with regard to the women working in SMEs and in disadvantaged regions, with a view to accompanying and even getting ahead of the technological advances. In terms of setting up programmes and national instruments, the Community programmes offer several opportunities which allow us to find solutions adapted to identified needs. The “Employment’ initiative contains a specific component (NOW initiative) aimed at creating new employment opportunities for women (for example, female entrepreneurs). Moreover, the ADAPT initiative plays an important role in the adaptation of workers to industrial changes.

Given the difficulties the sector encounters in taking better advantage of these programmes, the Commission, in the framework of social dialogue and its initiative in the sector of subcontracting, is also hoping to stimulate the development of transnational initiatives. These are aimed at spreading the results of better practices and savoir‐faire at European level; this should allow economic operators to become more aware.

The priority that the Commission gives to female employment can be seen in the new regulations on the Structural Funds and involves all future Community programmes. In addition, specific priority for the clothing and textiles sector, and more particularly for female employment in this sector, will constitute a determining factor in the identification of training requirements during the ex ante evaluation of the financial priorities of the specific programmes between the Commission and the Member States.

Many instruments are available to accompany and support at regional level the transformations of the sector. At Community level, the Structural Funds play an important role as a lever, especially in regions where the cost of investments or the social cost of restructuring is high (Retex, Community support frameworks, etcetera). In addition, the programmes for training workers to adapt to industrial changes contribute and will contribute in the future to the preservation of stable jobs in the Community (ADAPT and Employment).

For the next programming period (2000‐2006), the Commission approved, on 18 March 1998, a proposal for a regulation laying down general provisions on the Structural Funds. In this proposal, it puts forward, in particular, the implementation of a new Objective 2 which should support economic and social recovery in areas faced with restructuring in the industrial and services sector, rural areas in decline, urban areas in difficulty and areas in crisis which are dependent on fishing. The actions carried out today under the Retex initiative could be renewed in the context of this new Objective 2. The map of areas eligible for Objective 2 status will have to be coherent with that of the areas which receive aid from the Member States in accordance with paragraph 3© of Article 92 of the EC Treaty.

Question No 77 by Florus Wijsenbeek (H−0410/98)

Subject: P & I Marine Insurance

Is the Commission aware that the P & I Marine Insurance Scheme is in danger of becoming obsolete because Greek shipowners want to lower the maximum liability of participants and the Commission's DG IV keeps asking for the scheme to be made more versatile?

What is the Commission's assessment of the consequences for safety at sea of the discontinuation of the P & I Clubs?

Answer

The Commission believes that the system of Protection and Indemnity insurance established by the International Group of P&I Clubs is not in danger of disappearing as a consequence of the procedure that it has opened by issuing a Statement of Objections. This act concerns some aspects of the International Group's arrangements which are found to be in breach of the competition rules of the EC Treaty and which are not indispensable to the proper functioning of the P&I insurance system.

The Commission considers that this system brings important benefits to the maritime industry. It seeks to obtain a solution that, while preserving these benefits, would eliminate its anti‐competitive features.

As to the second question, the Commission does not see any reason to believe that there may be a ‚discontinuation of the P&I Clubs’. Its Statement of Objections is not addressed to the arrangements concluded within the individual P&I Clubs but to the International Group's agreements, which are concluded between some of these individual Clubs.

Question No 78 by Anna Karamanou (H−0412/98)

Subject: War scenarios in children's electronic games

According to a recent investigation by the Greek newspaper, Kathimerini, the war industries have found suitable territory for expanding their business enterprises in the games market with the aid of simulation technology. Using war scenarios and simulated battlefields, children are trained in the techniques of war, the use of violence, in cunning and guile in order to become the 'super‐warriors' of tomorrow. The deserts of Iraq and Kuwait are the settings for games such as Desert Tank, Super Battletank, M1 Abrahams and Desert Strike in which the players are called on to drive tanks and pilot helicopter gunships and destroy the hideouts of the 'non‐Christian terrorists'.

What measures will the Commission take to protect the minds of children from all such profiteers and warmongers and how will it intervene to pass on to the new generation European peaceful values and a rejection of war and violence as a means of resolving differences?

Answer

The protection of the mental and moral development of children is obviously a subject which merits maximum attention from public authorities.

Toys are not products which could be considered to be simple consumer goods. They undoubtedly play a role in the development and education of a child. At European level, toys come under Directive 88/378/EEC which aims to both do away with barriers to intra‐Community trade and guarantee a high level of safety for consumers, thanks to the definition of essential safety requirements.

However, the Commission would like to point out that the Community legislation in force does not apply to electronic war games. That legislation is aimed at defining safety requirements to protect users from physical injury.

The requirements relating to the mental health of children are not harmonized at Community level and consequently come under national law. The Commission can only justify a proposal for harmonization if it becomes aware that there is a sufficiently serious safety and/or health problem in all the Member States. The Member States can always take appropriate measures once they believe that the moral and mental development of minors can be harmed by the use of games which are likely to encourage violence and hatred. A harmonization of the requirements to be applied to such games could only take place if the measures involved conformed to the rules of the Treaty, particularly Articles 30 to 36, as well as to the principles laid down by the case‐law of the Court of Justice.

These requirements are expressly recognized by Community legislation in other sectors, particularly in the audiovisual field where a common minimum level of protection for minors is provided against programmes including scenes of gratuitous violence or broadcasts which contain any incitement to hatred on grounds of race, sex, religion or nationality (Article 22 of Directive 89/552/EEC on the pursuit of television broadcasting activities).

However, the Commission is not aware of any national measures aimed at regulating electronic war games, which could, if necessary, legitimize a harmonization at Community level.

In any case, Europe is able to take initiatives in the area of the protection of the physical, mental and moral development of children, outside the framework of technical harmonization. One example of this is the support actions in the field of education, such as the “Violence at school’ initiative, launched by the Commission in 1997, under which support is given to transnational pilot projects on preventing and combating violence in schools.

Question No 79 by Esko Seppänen (H−0413/98)

Subject: Court of Auditors report on net contributors

In its report for 1996 the Court of Auditors listed the various Member States' contributions to the European Union's own resources income and the amount paid back to them in subsidies. On this basis it is possible to calculate which are the 'net contributors'.

From the list it is clear that the biggest net contributor is Germany, but it is also clear that The Netherlands' share of the bill includes a much higher level of customs revenue than those of the other Member States. There can be no justification for counting these as part of The Netherlands' own resources.

Does the Commission consider that the Court of Auditors list of net contributors is correct, and what does the Commission propose to do to reduce the various Member States' shares of net payments in accordance with these countries' demands?

Answer

The Commission takes the view that simple arithmetic measures of net balances of the Member States are generally of limited meaning. The reality is more complex, and it is virtually impossible to arrive at a consistent definition of the net benefits from a Member States' financial relationship with the Community. Depending on how encompassing the definition of expenditure or of contributions is, one can easily arrive at different measures of the net balance. This non‐uniqueness of the net balance measures can lead to arbitrary definitions of net benefits; these are invariably misleading. For these reasons, the Commission does not produce estimates of net balances.

It is possible to construct estimates of net balances from data on expenditure and contributions reported in the Annual Report of the Court of Auditors. These data are prepared and reported under the responsibility of the Court and their reliability depends on the assumptions used to construct the series. These assumptions concern, for example, the treatment of expenditure which is not possible to allocate to specific Member States, or whether to include or exclude contributions from traditional own resources. Evidently, depending on these assumptions the resulting data can differ seriously from other estimates.

Traditional own resources are fundamentally the true own resources of the Community. Consequently, they should not be treated as if belonging to any specific Member State or that they are part or its contributions to the Community budget. The Honourable Member is correct in pointing out that customs revenues should not be regarded as national contributions.

The Commission does not wish to comment on the correctness of the data reported in the Court of Auditors Annual Report. As noted previously, these data are the complete responsibility of the Court.

Furthermore, as pointed out in the document presented to the ECOFIN Council in October 1997 entitled ‚Budget contributions, EU expenditure, budgetary balances and relative prosperity of the Member States’, the Commission believes that while gross budget contributions are becoming increasingly more equitable, the expenditure side of the budget plays a crucial role in the development of budgetary imbalances. The Commission has already taken note of the fact that for some Member States the question of equity in contributions remains to be addressed. To this effect, the Commission will review these issues in a forthcoming report on the performance of the own resources system. The paper is expected to be available in autumn 1998.

Question No 80 by Sören Wibe (H−0415/98)

Subject: Commission proposal for new agricultural policy

The Commission's proposal for a new agricultural policy, reducing aid and prices so that the EU adjusts to the world market is to be welcomed in general terms. However, the partial compensation proposed – that aid will continue for maize silage for fodder – does not apply in Sweden and Finland.

Will Swedish and Finnish farmers not be hit relatively harder by not receiving the same compensation as other countries' farmers when the agricultural policy is reformed?

Answer

The Commission's proposals will allow the European agricultural industry to adapt to growing international markets rather than to be increasingly constrained by the generally poor internal market. To do so, it is proposed that support prices will be gradually reduced with compensation mainly in the form of direct payments.

Since its initial proposal for a 10 % milk price decrease last year, the Commission is convinced that a greater price reduction, to −15 % would bring benefits on several fronts, not least to consumers. The Community market situation will be eased because exports without subsidies will increasingly be possible, this will allow an increase in the milk quota. It is also a clear signal that the present quota system is too rigid and a more dynamic response is needed to increase competitiveness and meet market demand.

As regards cereal – mostly maize – silage, for reasons of control and administration it is difficult to suppress the payments for maize silage as when farmers make their claim, many do not know whether the maize will be harvested for grain or for silage. In these circumstances it is reasonable to also count the increase in payments for maize silage against the loss in income from price decreases.

As pointed out, there are regions where maize cannot be grown, particularly in mountain and Nordic areas. To reflect the problems of restructuring milk production in these regions, where climatic conditions are the least favourable there is an extra allocation of milk quota in proportion to milk production in these areas. Finland and Sweden are beneficiaries of this allocation.

Question No 81 by Arthur Newens (H−0420/98)

Subject: European business and the Helms Burton act

In view of the adverse effects on European businesses caused by the Helms Burton legislation, would the Commissioner state if there are any plans to refer this matter back to the disputes panel of the World Trade Organisation?

Answer

The Community and the US are currently negotiating in order to reach an agreement under the terms of the 11 April 1997 Understanding on the Helms‐Burton and D'Amato.

In accordance with that Understanding, the Community agreed to suspend its WTO case regarding the Helms‐Burton Act. Under WTO rules a panel may only remain suspended for a maximum of 12 months. That period expired on 21 April 1998.

If we are not able to find a solution to this dossier, the possibility to resume the Community WTO case remains.

It will be recalled that in April 1997 the Council decided that if action is taken against Community nationals, or waivers as described in the Understanding are not granted, ’the Commission will request the WTO to restart, or to re‐establish, the panel, which will then follow its natural course’. This possibility thus covers also the situation after 21 April 1998.

In the event that the Community wished to re‐establish the panel after 21 April, new consultations would have to be held. As a consequence, activation of a future panel would be slowed down, but only by a matter of some weeks. New consultations would, however, also enable the case to be broadened to include possible sanctions against Community companies taken by the US under ILSA.(11)

Question No 82 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0421/98)

Subject: Swedish Constitution and third stage of EMU

The Commission's report of 25 March 1998 concerning which countries are considered eligible for participation in the third stage of EMU noted that Sweden had not brought its rules sufficiently into line with the ESCB's Statute. Neither did the Commission consider the pending proposal to amend the Constitution in regard to the status of the Central Bank to be satisfactory. In Sweden the status of the Central Bank is regulated by the Constitution.

Does the Commission consider that further amendment to the Constitution is required, in addition to that now pending, before Sweden can be accepted as a full member of EMU?

Answer

The Commission believes, as it stated in its convergence report of 25 March 1998, that Swedish legislation is not compatible with the EC Treaty and the ESCB"s Statute. The Commission points out the following points which are incompatible.

The independence of the central bank will only be guaranteed after the general elections in September 1998, when the next parliamentary assembly will have adopted the amendments to the Constitution, through the Riksdag and Riksbank Acts. Those amendments should enter into force on 1 January 1999.

Moreover, the current government bill does not complete the integration of the central bank into the ESCB. It is up to the national legislature to determine which legislative acts must be adopted to this end. For example, the provisions on the powers of the central bank in the field of monetary policy still do not recognize the ESCB"s authority in this matter.

Question No 83 by Carlos Carnero González (H−0423/98)

Subject: Future of the Agfa‐Gevaert production centre in Aranjuez (Spain)

In 1996 the management of Agfa‐Gevaert (Bayer) gave an undertaking to the works council of the Aranjuez production plant that current levels of activity would be maintained until the year 2000 but has still not specified any subsequent intention, despite the proximity of that date.

Does the Commission take the view that the European Union should urge Agfa and, where appropriate, Bayer to do everything possible to guarantee future production in the Aranjuez centre at current levels of employment?

Can the Commission urge Agfa to inform the works council of its intentions regarding the future of the plant after the year 2000 as soon as possible and to consult the works council, as the body representing workers, in accordance with the directives in force?

Answer

It is not for the Commission to intervene in management decisions taken by companies, even when they have a significant impact on workers' interests and on jobs. The Commission does, of course, require that such decisions are taken in accordance with the relevant Community legislation, and is particularly sensitive to cases of corporate restructuring. It monitors the correct implementation of such legislation by the Member States which are primarily responsible for dealing with individual cases such as that referred to by the honourable Member.

It would appear from the information provided that the European Works Council Directive(12) applies in the case of this undertaking. Furthermore, the Collective Redundancies Directive(13) requires, if a reduction of employment levels is being considered, that employers inform and consult worker representatives before collective dismissals are effected.

It is also worth recalling in this context the planned new proposal for a general framework on worker information and consultation, which is due to be launched shortly.

Question No 84 by Nikolaos Papakyriazis (H−0425/98)

Subject: Desecration of a graveyard in Istanbul

On Wednesday, 1 April 1998, 51 graves in the Agios Eleftherios Greek Orthodox graveyard in Istanbul were desecrated. This was the worst act perpetrated in a Christian burial ground during the last decade. In recent months, the Greek Orthodox community in Istanbul has been the victim of a growing number of acts of provocation and aggression, while no official reaction has been forthcoming from the Turkish Government.

In view of developments concerning relations between the European Union and Turkey, what steps will the Commission take in response to this problem and what explanations, measures and guarantees will it seek to obtain from the Turkish Government regarding the protection of the Greek Orthodox community in Turkey and respect for its rights, given that acts such as those described above are inconceivable and unacceptable for the European Union?

Answer

The Commission has gathered information on the deplorable act described by the Member. According to this information, the Turkish authorities have neither formally condemned the desecration of the Saint Eleuthère Greek Orthodox graveyard, nor taken any action in relation to the acts carried out. The Commission naturally condemns these acts.

As regards the more general framework of relations with Turkey, the Commission firmly adheres to the conclusions of the Luxembourg European Council of December 1997. The Council recalled that the strengthening of Turkey"s links with the European Union is also dependent on the continuation of the political and economic reforms that that country has begun, particularly in bringing its standards and practices in the field of human rights into line with those in force in the European Union. The Council added that a strengthening of these links is also dependent on the respect and protection of minorities.

The Commission plans to continue to inform its Turkish representatives of the European Union"s concerns regarding these issues.

Question No 85 by Aline Pailler (H−0426/98)

Subject: 'New transatlantic market' plan

On 11 March the Commission presented a plan for a 'new transatlantic market'. Can the Commission say by what majority this plan was adopted? Commissioner Brittan has since been to the United States to present the plan. Can the Commission say what mandate it received from the Council to begin representations and organize meetings which resemble the opening of discussions with the Americans?

Answer

The Internal Rules of the Commission state that Commission decisions are taken by qualified majority. A vote is only taken if so requested by any Member. In this case, no such request was made, so the Communication on the New Transatlantic Marketplace was adopted by the Commission without a vote on 11 March 1998. The Commission's Communication represents a contribution to the process started with the adoption of the New Transatlantic Agenda (NTA) in 1995. The NTA commits the Community and the US to strengthen further and adapt their partnership. In particular, both sides undertake, without detracting from cooperation in multilateral fora, to create a New Transatlantic Marketplace by progressively reducing or eliminating barriers that hinder the bilateral flow of goods, services and capital.

At the December 1997 EU‐US Summit, it was agreed to develop further this concept. The proposals contained in the Communication have been discussed at various levels in the Council. The Commission has also informally discussed them with the US side, which has shown a keen interest in pursuing them so as to further liberalise trade and investment to the mutual benefit of our citizens and firms. Further to the presidency's summary of the GAC discussions of this point on 27 April, the presidency, working with the Commission, is bringing forward a proposal for an EU‐US Summit statement in order to take forward the New Transatlantic Agenda signed in 1995, taking full account of Member States' sensitivities, with the aim of promoting multilateral liberalization, as well as enhanced bilateral cooperation by progressively reducing or eliminating barriers that hinder the flow of goods, services and capital.

Question No 87 by Nuala Ahern (H−0429/98)

Subject: The NTL−11 spent nuclear fuel transport flask which has been used for over 20 years to ship highly radioactive nuclear wastes to Sellafield, UK

On 13 February and 5 and 6 March this year respectively, British Nuclear Fuels physically tested the integrity of the NTL−11 spent nuclear fuel transport flask – which has been used for over 20 years to ship highly radioactive nuclear wastes from Germany and Switzerland to Sellafield – at the Winfrith atomic research centre in the UK. The flask failed all three tests as the bolts used to secure the lid sheared. Over 130 transports have been made to Sellafield to date using this flask type. When was the Commission informed of this flask safety failure; what knowledge did the Commission have of the problem before these test failures; and what is the Commission now doing about testing all other flask types used in the Community?

Answer

The Commission was informed about the results of the test performed on the NTL−11 flask scale model at the end of March 1998. These tests showed an unexpected behaviour of the flask scale model shock absorber.

The 9m drop tests revealed a shearing of the 8 bolts by which the shock absorber is fixed to the lid. The lid shock absorber fulfilled its primary function in preventing immediate mechanical damage to the lid. The lid by itself is fixed by 32 bolts to the flask which remains undamaged. This means that the structural integrity of the flask was not questioned.

Nevertheless failure of the shock absorber at the 9m drop test might compromise the successive fire test at 800 degrees celsius during 30 minutes as required by the regulations.

The industry has withdrawn the 11 flask NTL−11 and others of similar design (5 NTL−11, 3 NTL−3 and 3 NTL−3 M) as a precaution. The competent authority has suspended the design approval certificates. If such an event should happen on a real flask during the transport of spent nuclear fuel no release of radioactive material from the flask would have occurred.

The Commission had no knowledge of the problem before the initial scale model test revealed on 13 February 1998 that there was a potential problem which was surprising for the industry and the UK competent authority as well.

Any further action rests with the United Kingdom as Member State of origin of design. The event will be reviewed and evaluated during the next Commission's Standing Working Group meeting on safe transport of radioactive material.

Question No 88 by Hadar Cars (H−0432/98)

Subject: Criteria for membership of EMU

According to the Commission's recommendation, Sweden is one of the countries which will not be able to take part in EMU from the outset in 1999. One of the reasons the Commission gives for this is that Sweden does not fulfil the monetary stability criterion because Sweden has not been a member of the ERM.

Is real monetary stability and/or membership of the ERM to be required for future membership of EMU (after the eleven members now approved)?

Answer

Article 109j (1) of the Treaty states that the Member States should have observed the normal fluctuation margins of the European monetary system for at least two years without devaluing against the currency of any other Member State. Article 3 of Protocol 6 gives a more detailed description of the exchange rate requirement regarding exchange rate stability: ’The criterion on participation in the exchange‐rate mechanism of the European Monetary System referred to in the third indent of Article 109j (1) of the EC Treaty shall mean that a Member State has respected the normal fluctuation margins provided for by the exchange‐rate mechanism on the European Monetary System without severe tensions for a least the last two years before the examination. In particular, the Member State shall not have devalued its currency's bilateral central rate against any other Member State's currency on its own initiative for the same period.’

In the Commission Convergence Report, the criterion is evaluated according to a framework where emphasis is put on (I) the participation of the ERM during the two‐year period before the examination, and (ii) the behaviour of a currency within the ERM in view of a narrow fluctuation margin around the ERM central rates. The interpretation of the Treaty in the Convergence Report thus emphasizes the stability of the exchange rate as well as the observance of the two‐year membership in ERM.

Neither the Treaty nor the Convergence Report lay down any detailed rules for the evaluation of the exchange rate stability criterion for potential members of the euro area after the third stage of EMU has started. However, a number of principles will be followed in the evaluation of future participants. These include the principle of equal treatment. The principle of equal treatment means the Member States joining at a later stage will not be confronted with additional requirements for joining.

Question No 89 by Caroline Jackson (H−0433/98)

Subject: US classification of genetically engineered crops

Can the Commission state whether there is any truth in the reports that the US Department of Agriculture is proposing changes to US organic food standards so as to allow, inter alia, genetically engineered crops and the products of intensive animal rearing systems to be classified as organic?

What is the Commission's reaction to these proposals if they are true?

Answer

The Commission can confirm that the draft National Organic Programme proposed by the US Department of Agriculture to propose changes to the US food standards does allow, inter alia , genetically engineered crops and certain intensive rearing practices for livestock production. In both cases, these products can be classified as organic.

The European Commission is submitting, under the arrangements provided for under the WTO agreement on technical barriers to trade, comments to the United States on their proposed regulation for organic farming. Particular concern has been expressed in the document with regard to the two issues indicated in the previous paragraph and also other aspects of interest.

Question No 90 by Gerard Collins (H−0434/98)

Subject: Additional Irish milk quota

Is the Commission aware that in 1984 when milk quotas were first introduced, an assurance was given on behalf of the Commission that in the event of additional milk quota becoming available, Ireland would be given priority in the allocation of same?

Answer

The reminder of the assurance given in 1984 to Ireland relating to a priority it could be given in the allocation of additional quotas must firstly be interpreted in the light of the situation of that Member State, which has a quota which has allowed it to preserve, and even to reinforce, its export capacity. In fact, Ireland has a guaranteed total quantity of 5 245 million tonnes, which is three and a half times greater than its internal consumption of 1.5 million tonnes.

Indeed, we must also remember that, since the beginning of the scheme and on several occasions, Ireland has already benefited from particularly favourable treatment. This was firstly evident at the time of the determination of the country"s historical base, in 1983, which was more favourable for this Member State than that of almost all of the other Member States (1981 production plus 1 %). In addition, Ireland has particularly benefited from the quantities from the Community reserve since, from the beginning, it has received 303 000 tonnes, out of a total allocation of 393 000 tonnes; that has largely compensated for the suspensions of 1987/88 and 1991/92, which has not been the case for the other Member States. Thus, Ireland currently has a guaranteed total quantity very similar to that which it had in 1984, while the other Member States only have an average of 90 % of the guaranteed total quantity of their initial quota.

Furthermore, almost 15 years have passed since the beginning of the scheme and the conditions affecting production and marketing have greatly changed since then, both within and outside the Community. These new limits and conditions cannot be ignored and justify the proposals made on 18 March 1998 by the Commission, which will be the subject of discussions in the framework of Agenda 2000 over the months ahead.

Question No 91 by Hiltrud Breyer (H−0436/98)

Subject: Mochovce – Walkdown report

Is the Commission aware that the Walkdown report for the Austrian Chancellery on the Mochovce nuclear power station points to serious safety shortcomings? Does it not agree with the report's assessment that it would be irresponsible to commission the plant this summer given the inadequate level of safety? Is the Commission aware that the planned safety concept for the Mochovce reactor would not meet the standards for approval in any EU Member State? Will the Commission include this matter in the accession negotiations?

Will the Commission take account of the Mochovce nuclear power station in the accession negotiations if the Walkdown II report recommends that commissioning of the plant should not go ahead this summer as planned because of the safety shortcomings and resulting threat to the population of the EU?

Answer

The Commission is well aware of the comments made by the Austrian Government in 1994 relating to the project of completion of Mochovce NPP. The comments made by the Austrian Government at that time referred mainly to the Safety Analysis Review performed by the consortium Riskaudit. These comments were analysed by Riskaudit and taken into consideration within the framework of the then planned Euratom and EBRD loan. After careful analysis, the conclusions of the consortium were that no serious safety deficiencies remained in the 1994 modernization projects if all their recommendations were taken into account by the plant.

After the discontinuation of the Euratom and EBRD procedures, the Commission scaled down its activities on this project. The present ongoing project within the PHARE programme relates to assessments of design and operational safety for the Mochovce NPP.

More in general, the Commission has identified in the Accession partnership for Slovakia the need of future enhancement of the independence and competence of the Slovak Nuclear Safety Regulator. It is also within this framework that developments towards further increase of nuclear safety levels in Slovakia are enhanced.

Question No 92 by Hugh Kerr (H−0437/98)

Subject: UK Government proposals to levy tuition fees on High Education

Will the Commission be examining the UK Government's plans to introduce tuition fees in high education to determine whether the proposals are in breach of European Union legislation on freedom of mobility for students? And if not, why not?

Answer

The Commission has monitored closely the development of policy in the United Kingdom with regard to the introduction from 1 September 1998 of a student contribution of up to £1, 000 per year towards tuition fees for study in full‐time higher education.

In itself the introduction of student contributions to tuition fees is not in breach of Community legislation. Indeed a number of other Member States already have such a system.

The fundamental principle of non‐discrimination on grounds of nationality, established in Community law, applies in all cases concerning admission to an education or training establishment, including enrolment or tuition fee requirements or the conditions governing the award of a grant to cover such fees. In this respect, any European Union citizen must be treated in the same way as national citizens.

The government of the United Kingdom has confirmed that the student tuition fee contribution, and the award of a meanstested grant to support students from lower‐income families, will apply equally to students from all Member States, with the exception of those students mobile in the framework of the ERASMUS chapter of the SOCRATES programme. Under the terms of this programme, students undertaking a study period abroad in a UK higher education institution must not be charged tuition fees by the host institution (although their home institution is permitted to continue to charge such fees to the student during this study period).

Moreover, in order to ensure that the new tuition fee regime does not have a negative impact on the willingness of British students to study abroad under SOCRATES/ERASMUS, the UK authorities have indicated that from 1999/2000 onwards British SOCRATES/ERASMUS students will not be required to make a tuition fee contribution to their home institution while undertaking their study period abroad. The Commission welcomes this proposal, which should help minimize any negative consequences of the new policy on student mobility within SOCRATES, and may indeed encourage a welcome increase in the numbers of British students taking advantage of the opportunity to study abroad.

Question No 93 by Nikitas Kaklamanis (H−0438/98)

Subject: Kozloduy nuclear power station and the health threat facing the inhabitants of northern Greece

According to statements made by official Bulgarian representatives, Bulgaria is refusing to shut down the antiquated reactors of the Kozloduy nuclear power station, in defiance of commitments it made to the EC (as it then was) in 1993. It had undertaken to shut down all the reactors by 1998, but it is now intending to keep them on stream until 2010. During a meeting of the Greek‐Bulgarian Interreg and Phare‐CBC Programme Monitoring Committee (9/12/97), Bulgarian representatives told their Greek partners that the waters of the Rivers Strymon and Nestos were contaminated with radioactivity. Will the Commission say what action it intends to take to oblige Bulgaria to shut down the Kozloduy nuclear power station which poses a very serious health threat for the inhabitants of the whole of northern Greece?

Answer

The Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant, situated on the Danube River close to the Romanian border, has six units. Units 1 to 4 are of the VVER 440‐230 type, the older type of soviet designed pressurised water reactors. Units 5 and 6 are of the most modern soviet reactor types, considered upgradable by the experts.

Bulgaria signed in 1993 an agreement with the Nuclear Safety Account of the EBRD. In the agreement, it was stated that Units 1 and 2 of the Kozloduy plant will be closed as soon as sufficient replacement energy is available by putting the Chaira pumping station on line and either the Varna thermal power plant or one of the Kozloduy 5 and 6 units are modernized.

For Units 3 and 4, the agreement states that they will be closed as soon as the energy situation allows it, but in any case as soon as Kozloduy 5 and 6 are modernised and conversion of Sofia, Kostov and Republika district heating plants to combined cycle co‐generation of heat and power is completed.

None of these conditions have been fulfilled yet. Present estimates consider that the shortest possible date to fulfil the conditions for closing down Units 1 and 2 is 2002. Units 3 and 5 could follow two years later.

The Commission has included in the Agenda 2000 the condition that Bulgaria, as a candidate country to join the Community, should strictly abide by the agreement with the Nuclear Safety Account regarding closing dates for Kozloduy 1 to 4.

The Commission considers that a way should be found to work with Bulgaria in order to enable it to give the right priority to nuclear safety and to develop realistic solutions to its energy problems, giving due consideration to the development of alternative energy sources and the more efficient use of energy.

Discussions should therefore he held with Bulgaria to establish a road map encompassing the whole energy sector and to develop – in close cooperation with the international financing institutions – financing schemes on which international financial support could be based. This will be done to the extent possible through existing mechanisms for cooperation, such as the subcommittees established by the European Agreements and in a way which is compatible with the process of implementation of the ‚Accession Partnerships’ and of the ‚National plans for adoption of the Acquis’ which will set out the priorities and the actions to be completed in the run‐up to the accession.

With regard to the reported contamination of the Strimonasnestos River, it should be noted that this contamination does not result from the nuclear power plant but from the past uranium mining activities near those rivers. In the framework of the INTERREG PHARE CBC programme, a rehabilitation project of this extraction site is programmed.

Question No 94 by Jean Querbes (H−0441/98)

Subject: Market in sheepmeat

In 1997, sheepmeat production fell in France, even though it increased in the Community as a whole. France currently produces less than 50 % of the sheepmeat it consumes. This unwelcome trend is likely to continue in view of the current fall in prices and incomes. Is the Commission going to propose Community measures which will do something to help sheepmeat producers, for example by restricting imports of sheepmeat from New Zealand?

Answer

It is true that the production of sheepmeat in France decreased in 1997 whilst production in some other Member States saw an increase. The amount of domestically produced lamb as a percentage of total consumption in France has generally been around 50 % although it should be noted that the market share taken by French produced lamb rose slightly in 1997.

It is clear that the Community sheepmeat market has been very depressed for the last few months. This situation has been mainly caused by a glut on the market caused by the carryover in the United Kingdom in particular, of a large number of lambs from last year but has also been aggravated by the continuing rise in imports of fresh, chilled products from New Zealand.

A meeting has already taken place to discuss this problem with the New Zealand Minister for International Trade and Agriculture who reiterated the commitment entered into by New Zealand at the time of the Uruguay Round negotiations to market their product in a responsible way and not undermine the stability of the market. He also expressed his willingness to enter into further consultations. Discussions on this sensitive issue will therefore continue at a technical level.

Question No 96 by Ulf Holm (H−0446/98)

Subject: Situation in Vitrolles

The administration of Vitrolles in southern France was recently taken over by the racist National Front party, and there has been a witch‐hunt directed at coloured people. Measures have included a 5000 franc benefit for every white baby born, and in the local library books designated as 'unpatriotic' and dealing with 'exotic cultures' have been weeded out. Coloured families have been denied welfare benefits. What will happen next?

Does the Commission intend to act to prevent such discrimination against coloured people, who are often not Union citizens? And if so, how?

Answer

The Commission has no information about the specific allegations made by the Honourable Member about the situation in Vitrolles, France. However, in the current state of development of European law, the implementation of legislation prohibiting racial discrimination is a matter of national competence.

Nevertheless, as regards social advantages, Article 48 of the EC Treaty and Regulation (EEC) 16 2/68(14) provides for the principle of equal treatment between nationals and other European workers and the members of their families. Thus, if the authorities of Vitrolles were to refuse child allowances to European Community workers or to the members of their families while granting them to French nationals, such discrimination would be contrary to European law. Such European rules are fully applicable to workers who are nationals of one Member State and to the members of their families, irrespective of their nationality.

Furthermore, Article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam includes a general non‐discrimination clause making it possible for the Council, acting unanimously on a proposal from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, to ‚take appropriate action to combat discrimination based on sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation’. As announced in its recent Action Plan against racism(15) , the Commission intends to present a legislative proposal to combat racial discrimination once the Treaty of Amsterdam is ratified.

Question No 97 by John Iversen (H−0449/98)

Subject: Beef promotion II

The Commission's answer to my Written Question P−0647/98 is unsatisfactory. It conflicts with the Commission's actual practice.

The Commission maintains that it has no view and will not intervene in the matters raised in my question, but that is precisely what it does in the regulation, (EEC) 1318/93(16) . This restricts aid to beef and veal from beef breeds and to calves of all breeds of less than 140 kg, which primarily means 'factory' calves. The Commission must therefore admit that it has adopted a position on the questions I asked. It must also acknowledge that the position it has adopted involves the setting of priorities mentioned in the question.

Does this mean that the Commission believes that factory calves transported from Denmark to the Netherlands are of higher quality than the same calves organically bred on the farms where they were born? And that forequarters of elderly suckler cows are of higher quality than fillet from totally grass‐fed bullocks of dairy or beef breeds?

Answer

The promotion programme for beef and veal is limited, through a decision by the Council, to quality beef and veal.

It is very difficult to define in a general way the quality of beef and veal. For that reason, a large degree of subsidiarity has been left to the Member States in this matter.

As regards mature cattle, it is planned to limit the scope to beef breeds and the first animals cross bred with dairy breeds. This definition means that the funds for promoting quality beef and veal are reserved for meat from animals reared for meat production, excluding therefore meat from animals where meat production is only a by‐product of milk production.

A similar distinction cannot be applied to the production of veal. In this type of breeding, the crucial point is that of the animals" wellbeing. Therefore, additional conditions have been inserted into the regulations, and particularly the respect, from 1 January 1999, of the requirements on group penning and on the minimum free space for each calf, although the gradual introduction of these elements has only been planned for 31 December 2006.

Question No 98 by Heidi Hautala (H−0450/98)

Subject: Staffing levels in DG VI

In 1991, a Task Force carried out a screening exercise to determine how many 'A' staff were needed to discharge the responsibilities of the Veterinary and Zootechnical legislation Unit of DG VI. Would the Commissioner say how many 'A' staff were recommended by the Task Force, how many are presently in post in that Unit and how many of these officials are either temporary agents or detached national experts? What steps are being taken to correct this unacceptable situation?

Question No 99 by Michael Elliott (H−0453/98)

Subject: Staffing levels in DG VI

Would the Commission explain what steps are being taken to correct the totally inadequate staffing levels in the Veterinary and Zootechnical legislation Unit of DG VI? Furthermore would the Commission explain why the commitment given to the Parliament in 1987, namely that there would be a permanent veterinary post responsible for animal welfare, is no longer being honoured and that the present incumbent is on a temporary contract which is due to be terminated in July 1998?

Joint Answer

The taskforce established for ‚Screening’ in 1991 recommended that 35 'A' staff were needed to discharge the responsibilities of the Veterinary and Zootechnical Legislation Unit of DG VI.

At present the unit has 20 'A' staff in post, assisted by 5 national experts. The 20 'A' staff are composed of 14 permanent officials and 6 temporary agents. A procedure for selection of temporary agents is underway to replace anticipated shortfalls.

Even though the contracts for temporary agents are limited in time, such as that for the official dealing with animal protection, the allocation for resources for this activity is permanent.

In 1997, 5 permanent posts were redeployed to the Veterinary and Zootechnical Legislation Unit, as well as 2 national expert posts. This was at a time when redeployment was also made within DG VI towards the Phytosanitary Unit, Clearance of Accounts, Simplification and Evaluation, as well as 17 posts to the Directorate General for Personnel for later redeployment to DG XXIV. In view of further internal redeployment to Clearance of Accounts, requested by the Parliament, as well as redeployment to cover the increased workload due to accession negotiations, it is difficult to imagine another major internal redeployment towards the veterinary unit in the near future.

Question No 101 by Paul Rübig (H−0454/98)

Subject: Waste water treatment in Athens

In connection with Directive 91/271/EEC(17) on urban waste water treatment, I should like to ask the Commissioner how waste water is treated in Athens. When is the planned improved waste water treatment plant expected to be completed?

Answer

In accordance with the obligations of Council Directive 91/271/EEC concerning urban waste water treatment(18) , the Athens agglomeration must be equipped with a secondary (biological) collecting and treatment system for urban waste water by 31 December 2000 at the latest.

According to the information the Commission has in its possession, a secondary treatment plant has existed since 1986 to the north of the Athens agglomeration, in Metamorphosis, which has a capacity for a population equivalent of 500 000 (the population equivalent is a unit of measurement currently used for organic pollution and is equivalent to the average organic load produced per person per day). For most of the agglomeration, the waste water has to be treated on the island of Psitalia, off the coast of Piraeus. A first phase of this treatment plant with a capacity for a population equivalent of 300 000, that is, the primary treatment plant (physical) was opened in 1994. The necessary work in terms of secondary treatment and the treatment of sludge arising from treatment must be carried out in the next two or three years.

These treatment plants have received and continue to receive funding from the Community. Thus, the secondary treatment and the treatment of sludge planned for the Psitalia plant were the subject of a decision on funding by the Cohesion Fund.

Following petition No 237/96 by Mr Alionatis and written question 765/98 by Mr Kaklamanis(19) , a Member of the European Parliament, the Commission has already prepared a request to the Greek authorities for additional information on the following matters: the timetable for the introduction of the secondary treatment and treatment of sludge in Psitalia; the nature and official situation of the direct discharges of urban waste water into the river Kifissos which runs through the Athens agglomeration; the official situation of the discharge of industrial waste water into the public network and into the Kifissos; and the type of treatment, the quantity and the destination of sludge arising from treatment which is and will be produced in Psitalia. This letter of request for information must be forwarded during May to the Greek authorities.

For all these matters the Commission is taking into consideration the respect of Community legislation and, in particular, the implementation of the provisions necessary for the respect of the 31 December 2000 deadline established by Directive 91/271/EEC.
