Question No 102 by Francisco Sanz Fernández (H−0457/98)

Subject: Revision of the Raphael programme's financial framework

As rapporteur for the RAPHAEL programme, I should like to ask the Commission if it has already drawn up the proposal for revising the programme's financial framework, as provided for in Article 8(3) of the Decision establishing the programme ('The financial framework... will be subject to re‐examination before the end of the second year, on a proposal from the Commission, in the light of the budgetary situation and the results obtained in the first phase of the programme'). Is the Commission aware of the importance of that re‐examination with regard to the programmes's budget for the next two years, especially as only ECU 8.8 m of the ECU 30 m provided for are still available and the future framework programme for culture is still no more than a project? Is it also aware of the urgency of carrying out the revision so that its results may be taken into account when the programme's budget for 1999 is set?

Question No 103 by Bárbara Dührkop Dührkop (H−0458/98)

Subject: Revision of the Raphael programme budget

As rapporteur for the 1999 EU general budget, and in view of the timetable for that budget's adoption, I should like to ask the Commission if it has already started work on the revision of the financial framework for the RAPHAEL programme, as provided for in Article 8(3) of the Decision establishing the programme, since the results of that revision will need to be taken into account during the first and second readings of the budget.

Joint answer

Decision 2228/97/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 October 1997 establishes a Community action programme in the field of cultural heritage (Raphaël programme) for the period from 1 January 1997 to 31 December 2000. It receives total appropriations of ECU 30 million.

Article 8(3) of this decision provides for a reexamination of the financial framework for the programme before the end of the second year, in the light of the budgetary situation and the results obtained in the first phase of the programme. Moreover, Article 10 of the same decision provides for the presentation, after the programme has been in operation for two years and six months, of an evaluation report on the results achieved, accompanied, where necessary, by appropriate proposals.

Taking into account the budgetary allocations in 1997 and 1998 for the B3‐2000 (Raphaël) item, ECU 8.8 million are still unused of the ECU 30 million available for the programme.

Moreover, the Commission adopted on 6 May 1998 the first Community framework programme on culture for the 2000‐2004 period. This framework programme consists, in particular, of a unique financial instrument for actions on cultural cooperation (“Culture 2000’ programme) which should follow on, after 1 January 2000, from the three current programmes (Kaleidoscope, Ariane and Raphaël). Article 7 of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on this unique instrument stipulates that the entry into force of the “Culture 2000’ programme on 1 January 2000 will bring the Raphaël programme to an end.

The Commission is aware of the importance of ensuring in the years ahead the continuity of cultural actions, particularly in the field of heritage, and is considering the possible additional approaches that could be developed in this framework.

Question No 104 by Laura González Álvarez (H−0460/98)

Subject: Natura 2000

Under the terms of the 'Habitats' directive the Member States are required to forward to the Commission a full, complete list of the sites they propose to incorporate into the Community 'Natura 2000' network, and indeed they were supposed to have done so by June 1995.

In view of the fact that seven of the Member States will be taken to the Court of Justice for having failed to forward their national list of sites for the 'Natura 2000' network to the Commission, could the latter say whether the delay caused by the seven Member States in question will prevent it from producing the Community list of 'Natura 2000' sites which it is required to draw up in June 1998 on the basis of the national lists? Which sites have been proposed by Spain and what action is the Commission going to take against that country which, in contravention of Directive 90/313(20) , has refused to allow NGOs to have access to the official national list of sites to be incorporated into the Community 'Natura 2000' network?

Answer

Spain has transmitted to the Commission in January 1998 an extensive list of candidate special areas of conservation, comprising a total of 588 sites covering 70250 km2. This communication of the Spanish authorities is under assessment by the Commission.

A number of other Member States(21) have not yet transmitted their lists. The Commission decided in April to take them to Court for their failure to comply with the obligations pursuant to Council Directive 92/43/EC, of 21 May 1992, on the conservation of natural habitats and wild fauna and flora(22) . This failure will of course prevent the Commission from meeting its obligation to produce a Community list by June this year.

The Commission learnt about Spain's failure to grant NGOs access to its official ‚national list’ and has raised the issue in writing with the Spanish authorities. Should the Spanish authorities not provide a satisfactory response, the Commission will take the necessary steps to ensure compliance with Council Directive 90/313/EEC, of 6 December 1990, on the freedom of access to information on the environment(23) .

Concerning the said list of sites proposed by Spain, it will be made public following evaluation and the preparation of a proposed Community list(24) .

As regards documents submitted by the Spanish authorities, the Commission would refer the honourable Member to such authorities. According to Commission Decision 94/90/ECSC, CE, Euratom(25) as amended by Commission Decision 95/567/Euratom, ECSC, EC(26) , on public access to Commission documents, the Commission shall only grant access to documents emanating from the Commission itself. If the document requested, held by the Commission, emanates from a natural or legal person, a Member State, another community Institution or body of any other national or international body, the application must be sent direct to the author.

Question No 105 by Richard Corbett (H−0469/98)

Subject: AIDS vaccine

Is the Commission aware of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative? What does it intend to do to follow up the commitment it entered into at the G8 Summit in Denver, namely to work to provide the resources required to accelerate AIDS vaccine research?

What, in particular, does it intend to do to coordinate the work of the various DGs involved, each of which deal with one aspect of the problem but without any overall strategy, and what funds does it envisage making available?

Answer

The Commission is indeed well aware of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI); and has followed its proceedings from its inception, and is following up the commitment entered into in the G8 Denver Summit.

The Commission is interested in general in initiatives likely to facilitate scientific progress in developing a safe and effective vaccine against HIV, and in encouraging collaboration and exchange of information among those working towards this.

As regards vaccine research, the BIOMEDICAL research programme of the BIOMED 2 (1994‐1998) supports at present 32 projects on AIDS with a total budget of ECU 16 million.

This policy to take forward HIV vaccine research is included in the Commission's proposal on the 5th Framework Programme on R&D (1998‐2002), in particular within Key action II ‚Control of viral and other infectious diseases’.

The international collaboration programme with developing countries (INCO‐DC) also supports a number of projects in the development of vaccines effective against HIV strains in developing countries.

A draft communication to the Council and the European Parliament on the “Increased solidarity to confront AIDS in developing countries’ initiative is being drawn up and will be forwarded to Parliament in the near future. This text is a response to the request by the Luxembourg European Council to study the procedures for setting up a treatment solidarity fund aimed at combatting AIDS in developing countries; it sets out the possibilities and procedures for the specific contribution by the Community in response to the AIDS epidemic in developing countries both in terms of prevention – including vaccinations – and treatment.

The different Directorates‐General implicated in the fight against AIDS, in particular DG V (Public Health), DG III (Pharmaceuticals), DG VIII (cooperation with developing countries) and DG XII (Research) are working together continuously through an AIDS interservice coordination.

Question No 106 by Mark Killilea (H−0470/98)

Subject: Report on seals

Can the Commission inform me how soon it is proposed to make public the scientific research it has carried out on the effect of seals on fisheries and fish stocks in EU waters? Given that this report has been finalized since 1997, can it explain why it has not yet been presented?

Answer

It is assumed that the honourable Member is referring to the report ‚The physical interactions between grey seals and fishing gear’ (Ref: PEM/(93/06). This report concerns a study carried out by the Irish Sea Fisheries Board and which was co‐financed by the Commission.

Reports on studies co‐financed by the Commission do not necessarily reflect the views of the Commission. It is the responsibility of the contractor of the study (in this case the Irish Sea Fisheries Board), should it so choose, to make public the results (for example through appropriately recognised scientific journals).

The Commission suggests that the honourable Member approaches the Irish Sea Fisheries Board to obtain a copy of the above‐mentioned study.

Question No 107 by Pedro Marset Campos (H−0473/98)

Subject: Environmental disaster in the Doñana area (Seville and Huelva, Spain)

On 25 April last a dam holding back 5 million cubic metres of water containing acid and heavy metals from the mines at Aznalcóllar (Seville) caused an environmental disaster in the Doñana area whose impact is as yet unknown but threatens to contaminate the national park, a place unique in Europe for its variety of wildlife species.

Furthermore, the floodwaters seriously damaged more than 4 800 hectares of agricultural land, in particular olive and citrus groves, cereals, rice and cotton fields, and as yet the scale of the impact on the river Guadalquivir and its estuary is unknown, although it seems likely to destroy the ecosystem and fish resources in the region.

Has the Commission taken any steps yet to reduce to a minimum the effects of this environmental disaster?

Answer

The Spanish authorities have designated the Doñana national park a special protection area for birds in accordance with Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds(27) . The Spanish authorities have also proposed that the national park and the natural park be added to the list in Article 4 of Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora(28) as sites which could be integrated into the Natura 2000 network.

The Commission asked the Spanish authorities for information on the circumstances in which this environmental disaster occurred, on the past, present and future measures aimed at protecting the national park and its surroundings, and on the actions that have been initiated with a view to minimizing the consequences of the accident.

There is currently no Community regulation on liability for damage caused to the environment. It is therefore up to the competent national authorities, once the causes of the disaster have been established, to resolve this matter with respect to the applicable provisions of Spanish law.

Within its own competence, the Commission is obviously willing to consider with the Spanish authorities all measures to be taken in order to minimize the effects of this environmental disaster. It has also offered the Spanish authorities its assistance in the framework of Community cooperation on civil protection and environmental emergencies. The Commission remains in close contact with those authorities to monitor the accident and to provide, if the case arises, the necessary assistance.

The Commission sent a letter to the Spanish Minister for the Environment in order to express its regrets following this disaster.

Question No 108 by Carmen Díez de Rivera Icaza (H−0484/98)

Subject: Irresponsibility and tragedy in the Coto de Doñana

In 1995 a complaint was submitted to the Commission concerning the risk of the dam bursting as a result of the activities of the Bolinden‐Apirsa plant at Aznalcóllar near the outstanding nature reserve of Coto de Doñana.

Can the Commission explain what steps were taken at that time which led to the file on the complaint being closed by the Commission in 1997?

Answer

At the end of 1995 the Commission received a complaint on the pollution of the water in the rivers Agrio and Guadiamar by dangerous substances from mining activities by the company Boliden‐Apirsa S.L. in Aznalcollár.

In considering the complaint, the Commission asked the Spanish authorities for their observations on the facts of the matter. The case was discussed at the package meeting on complaints and infringement procedures relating to the environment which took place in Madrid in November 1996.

The Spanish authorities informed the Commission of the measures taken to prevent pollution. These measures included the construction of two impermeable panels to prevent the accumulated water from reaching the river Agrio; the opening of a canal leading the water to a pumping point; the installation of a panel at the south of the deposit site which collects the filtrations and leads them to the abovementioned pumping point; the installation of well pumps along the deposit site adjoining the river Agrio; and the routing of the water from the deposit site towards the treatment plant via a closed pipe.

In 1997, the complainant was informed by the Commission of the response from the Spanish authorities and was invited to supply new information which would allow the Commission to continue with the consideration of the file. The complainant has not replied to this letter.

On the basis of the information provided by the Spanish authorities indicating that the measures needed to resolve this situation had been taken, and given that it had no new information, the Commission decided to close the file on 25 March 1998. The complainant was subsequently informed by the Commission of its decision to close the matter.

Question No 109 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H−0478/98)

Subject: Measures to prevent the death of young immigrants

What measures will the Commission take to ensure that this summer does not see further deaths of young immigrants attempting to reach Europe by crossing the Straits of Gibraltar in makeshift vessels? Will the EU take action or make joint efforts with Morocco to develop the industrial centres of northern Morocco, mount information campaigns to deter such attempts and combat mafia elements seeking to take advantage of this situation?

Answer

It is by combating underdevelopment, which is at the root of illegal immigration, that the Community and Morocco will be able to avoid the events mentioned by the Member.

The Commission is in fact very aware of the problem posed by the underdevelopment of the northern provinces of Morocco, the region where most illegal immigration towards the Community originates.

The Commission shares the Moroccan government"s concern to develop the 13 northern provinces and is currently funding, in the framework of the Euro‐Mediterranean partnership, projects to a total cost of ECU 307 million which cover the fields of rural and social development as well as education and health.

Moreover, the Commission has just signed, with the Moroccan government, an indicative programme for 1999 within the MEDA programme which provides for an additional ECU 112 million for northern Morocco for the protection of the environment, for non industrial fishing and for the construction of the northern bypass.

Question No 110 by Liam Hyland (H−0479/98)

Subject: Undeclared cash savings and the euro

It is suggested that large, undeclared cash savings exist in certain, if not all, Member States.

How does the Commission envisage using the opportunity arising from the need for the conversion of undeclared currencies into euros, particularly if such monies derive from suspected criminal actions, and what action does it propose to take to ensure that criminal earnings are identified and those responsibilities for the underlying crimes are brought to justice?

Answer

It is possible that at the time of the changeover to the euro large amounts of dormant cash in national currencies will be presented to financial institutions for conversion alongside the cash in active circulation. However, there is also a possibility that such cash will be spent or otherwise changed or disposed of in the period leading up to the changeover.

Mechanisms already exist in all the Member States to prevent the laundering through the financial system of the proceeds of crime. These mechanisms are based on the 1991 anti‐money laundering Directive, the Vienna and Strasbourg Conventions and the 40 Recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering.

The European Directive at present prohibits only the laundering of the proceeds of drugs trafficking. An extension of this scope is one of the points currently being considered by the Commission in its work on a possible updating and extension of the Directive. In fact, virtually all the Member States have criminalised the laundering of the proceeds of a much wider range of serious offences. Some Member States have decided to use the anti‐money laundering defences as a means of combating tax fraud.

Under the Directive, banks and other financial institutions are obliged to identify clients opening accounts or establishing durable business relations and keep the necessary records. These requirements also apply to clients seeking to effect one‐off transactions amounting to more than ECU 150 000. Care must also be taken to spot cases where clients appear to be carrying out multiple smaller transactions in order to keep under this threshold. The institutions covered by the Directive are in all cases obliged to report any suspicions of money laundering to the competent authorities, though the extent of this obligation depends on the range of underlying criminal offences covered by the money laundering legislation.

It is the Commission's firm position that the provisions of the Directive will continue to be fully applicable at the time of the changeover to the euro.

The particular technical problems linked to the application of the anti‐money laundering defences during the euro changeover period have already been referred to in the Money Laundering contact Committee set up under the Directive. The Commission intends to continue its reflection on these issues and to continue the discussions in the Contact Committee.

***

Question No 111 by Niall Andrews (H−0480/98)

Subject: EU response to cybercrime

According to recent reports, criminal prosecutions of computer hackers have more than doubled in the US this year. Vital services such as telecommunications and banking can be put at risk. Hacking tools are increasingly available on the Internet.

Will the Commission state what action it is proposing to prevent cybercrime in the European Union, and will it reveal what information it has on cybercrime in the European Union?

Answer

The Commission shares the honourable Parliamentarian's concerns with regard to the negative impacts of cybercrime. Already in 1996 it commissioned a study on high‐tech crime which was completed in the end of 1997. The study has raised awareness that problems with illegal content might have repercussions on the acceptance of new technology. On the basis of the recommendations made by the study the Commission is currently discussing its follow‐up, including a possible communication on the issue of cybercrime. Actions are currently taking place in the third pillar, in implementation of the Action Plan to combat organized crime.

On a broader international level, the Commission has been actively participating as an observer in the work of the P−8 and the Council of Europe on the subject of high‐tech crime. Thus, the Union, as well as the other fora where the phenomenon of cybercrime is discussed, can enjoy the synergetic effects of their work and the Commission can contribute to a coordinated approach on the matter.

The Action Plan Promoting the Safe Use of the Internet – proposed by the Commission and currently before the European Parliament and Council – falls also under activities to combat high‐tech crime in the broader sense. It provides inter alia for the co‐financing of projects such as self‐regulatory activities, filtering and rating mechanisms and awareness activities.

As far as statistical data on cybercrime are concerned, it is difficult to obtain reliable data given the broadness of the phenomenon and the reluctance of victims, such as banks, credit card companies etc., to report damages suffered. Nevertheless, estimates for the telephone companies amount to hundreds of millions ECU lost per year created by fraudulous manipulations of their software. Developments show a considerable increase in illegal activities in cyberspace due to the growing use of the new means of communication.

Question No 112 by James Fitzsimons (H−0481/98)

Subject: Dangerous toys

In April 1998, Irish consumers were warned that many soft plastic toys are dangerous because they contain certain chemicals, and a call was made for the EU temporarily to ban PVC toys, pending further research into the issue.

Is the Commission aware of the growing concern about the level of phthalates which are added to PVC to make it softer and more flexible, is it aware that young children may chew the toys and ingest potentially harmful chemicals, and will it indicate its response to this call for a ban?

Answer

The Commission has indeed received several notifications from Denmark and Spain within the framework of the emergencies procedure of Article 8 of Directive 92/59/EEC (General Product Safety) concerning measures taken to withdraw from the market certain toys and child‐care articles in soft PVC containing phthalates.

The Commission has consulted Member States on this issue and these consultations have highlighted the need for scientific opinion on the risks associated with products. therefore, the Commission has requested the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, Ecotoxicology and the Environment (SCTEE) to give its opinion on the impact on children's health of the use of soft PVC containing phthalates in child‐care articles and toys, the limits which ought to be respected in relation to the migration of phthalates from these products, the test method to be followed and the standards or parameters that should be taken into consideration to measure the phthalate migration level.

The SCTEE, in its opinion of 24 April 1998, has reached the conclusion that the low margin of safety for the most used phthalate (DINP) give reason for concern. The SCTEE reached this conclusion by establishing tolerable exposure values for phthalates, incorporating a sufficient margin of safety, and comparing these values to an estimated exposure, which was calculated using what may be a worst‐case approach. This approach was chosen because there are uncertainties with respect to assessing the actual exposures applying the current model values. The SCTEE is aware of ongoing research on extraction methods, involving also adult human volunteers and has stated that its’present evaluation may be modified when the results of such studies become available.’

On the other hand, the present assessment process has not taken into account that more than one phthalate may occur in children's toys, that there may be additional exposures through food, air and dermal contact to these phthalates and the possible enhanced sensitivity of young children to the effects of phthalates.

The Commission is currently assessing the consequences of this opinion, in order to establish the possibility of short, medium and long‐term actions allowing the highest level of protection of the health and safety of children as well as the free circulation of goods within the Community.

In the short term the Commission is assessing the need for and the feasibility of a rapid response by means of a Decision of temporary, preventive nature under the Directive on general product safety, concerning products for which certain Member States have taken action. The possibility of this kind of action has also been discussed with the Member States in the framework of the Emergencies Committee of Directive 92/59/EEC.

It is envisaged in the medium term, considering restrictions on the placing on the market of potentially dangerous childcare articles and toys for infants not respecting migration limits as set by the SCTEE and tested on the basis of agreed protocols.

In the long‐term a revision of Directive 76/769/EEC relating to restriction on the marketing and use of certain dangerous substances and preparations may be considered taking into account the results of the research presently carried out by several Member States on phthalates. First results are expected in the course of this year. This will allow the Commission and the Member States to address the problems raised by these substances in a more comprehensive fashion.

Question No 113 by Elly Plooij‐van Gorsel (H−0482/98)

Subject: Advertisement of EU posts with age limits in the Member States

As the Commission is aware, draft legislation in the Netherlands which will ban age limits in recruitment advertising is due to pass through the Second House after the national elections in May.

How does the Commission propose to advertise posts for Commission officials with the new maximum age limits of 45 years in the Netherlands, once this legislation is in force? Has the Commission taken advice from its legal department on placing advertisements for Commission posts in the national media in the Netherlands?

Answer

The draft legislation in the Netherlands, which will ban age limits in recruitment advertising, is part of a general evolution in most Member States towards abolishing discrimination on the basis of age. This general trend is also reflected in the new article 6a of the Amsterdam Treaty which extends the principle of non‐discrimination to cover discrimination on the basis of age.

In this context, the Commission has, on 21 January of this year, adopted the political principle of abandoning age limits in its recruitment procedures whilst considering, however, that this principle should be implemented on the basis of a common agreement between the European institutions. This is the reason why the Commission, as an intermediary step, decided to raise the age limit to 45 years for all competitions at basic career level and this in parallel with the decision taken by the Bureau of the Parliament on 20 October 1997 to raise the age limit to 45.

There is nothing in Community legislation which prevents a Member State from adopting legislation banning age discrimination. Several Member States have already done so or are planning to do so. And they can only be encouraged to move in that direction in the context of the perspective of the entry into force of Article 6a of the Amsterdam Treaty.

However, from a strictly legal point of view, Annex III of the Staff Regulations which are a Council Regulation, permit age limits and when it comes to advertising recruitment procedures for the European institutions, the Staff Regulations, being a Council regulation, will prevail.

This said, the Commission would like to stress that its final objective is to abandon age limits and that discussions on the issue will be pursued within the framework of interinstitutional cooperation. The time necessary to reach an agreement between the institutions should allow for examination of the potential impact of such a measure, not only in terms of career management but also in the more general perspective of possible review of the recruitment system as such.

Question No 114 by Christine Oddy (H−0483/98)

Subject: Medical and Scientific Aid for Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia

Is the European Commission aware of the organization 'Medical and Scientific Aid for Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia' and its work with harelip/cleft palate patients (which has a particularly high rate of occurrence as a result of the civil wars)?

What projects does the European Commission support in this field?

Answer

The priorities in the field of health which are defined by the communication from the Commission to the Council and to the European Parliament, COM(77)94, emphasize the development of health systems and the quality and accessibility of primary health care (PHC).

In the countries mentioned, the Commission"s programmes are therefore directed towards maternal health care and child care, reproduction and the fight against the great endemics which correspond to the definition of primary health care.

Reconstruction surgery of cleft palates, which requires specific techniques and skills, is not recognized as an essential priority given the range of public health needs which come under primary health care.

The organization “Medical and Scientific Aid for Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia’ is not known to the Commission.

Question No 115 by Pat Gallagher (H−0486/98)

Subject: Creating a common market between the EU and the US and the consequences for the fishing industry in Ireland

In Chapter 9 of its Communication on the creation of a common market between the European Union and the United States, published in late March, the Commission states that, while fish and fish products are not excluded from the proposed NTMA (New Transatlantic Marketplace Agreement) in principle, the specificity and sensitivity of the fisheries sector may require a selective approach and that account be taken of the current Council debate on the future of the market in fisheries products in the European Union.

In view of the importance of the fishing industry to Ireland, both off‐shore and on‐shore, will the Commission outline the advantages of this initiative for Ireland?

Answer

The advantages of a greater liberalization of international trade must be assessed both at the level of the Community and at the level of each Member State.

As far as the fisheries sector is concerned, although in principle fish products are not excluded from the NTMA, the specificity and sensitivity of this sector requires a selective approach, which implies that the scope of a possible liberalization will be limited and will not include all fish products.

In any case, the definitive position of the Community on the fisheries sector will depend on the results of the current discussions concerning the Communication of the Commission on the future of the market for fish products in the European Community, as well as the current discussions between the Community and the United States on a reinforcement of the transatlantic economic partnership.

Question No 116 by Brian Crowley (H−0487/98)

Subject: Regional airports

Has the European Commission investigated the need for an increased allocation of financial resources from the European Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, in the next round of European Union structural fund monies, to be spent on the upgrading of the regional air transport network system in peripheral countries?

Answer

The major part of the Structural Fund resources for the next programming period will be used in support of programmes negotiated on the basis of regional development strategies proposed by the Member States. Particular needs with regard, for example, to transport infrastructure would be determined at this stage in the context of the overall strategic approach agreed between the Commission and the Member States.

The Commission's proposal for a new implementing regulation for the Cohesion Fund does not foresee a change in the scope of the type of measures eligible for assistance. The Commission has proposed that the Cohesion Fund should assist transport infrastructure which is identified in the guidelines adopted by the European Parliament and the Council in their joint decision No 1692/96 of 23 July 1996. It is then up to the Member States to submit applications for individual projects within the framework of those guidelines.

Question No 117 by MaLou Lindholm (H−0489/98)

Subject: Ban on seal hunting

On 18 April 1996, I put an oral question to the Commission concerning statistics which showed that Member States were not complying with the EU ban on imports of skins of certain seal pups, i.e. whitecoats and bluebacks, and products derived therefrom (89/370/EEC)(29) . In her answer, Commissioner Bjerregaard promised that she would naturally inquire into the matter more closely, as it was of course intended that the ban should be complied with. In view of that answer and of the fact that Inspector of Seal Hunting Lindberg filed a complaint with the Commission on 27 April 1998, will the Commission state what the promised inquiry found and what action it will take both on the basis of those findings and of the information contained in the aforementioned complaint?

Answer

The Commission has not (yet) received the complaint referred to by the honourable Member of Parliament.

Commission trade data for the years 1995 through 1997 indeed indicate substantial imports into the Community of whitecoat and blueback pup skins under nomenclature codes 43017010 (raw skins), 43021941 (tanned skins) and 43031010 (finished products). The Commission will submit these data to the Member States concerned and request them to establish whether they are correct and, if so, whether the skins and products concerned have been imported under the derogation applicable to those resulting from the traditional hunt by the Inuit people.

However, in view of the absence of a large scale commercial whitecoat hunt, import figures for the three years concerned totalling ECU 3.5 m and, in particular, on internal Community trade amounting to ECU 4.4 m, would appear to be unrealistic. Earlier Commission investigations of similar alleged imports demonstrated that lamb skins had been wrongly declared under the nomenclature codes created for whitecoat and blueback skins.

Question No 118 by Jens‐Peter Bonde (H−0343/98)

Subject: The Treaty of Amsterdam and the ending of existing border controls

Will the provisions of Article 14(2) of the EC Treaty (post‐Amsterdam consolidated version) relating to an area without internal frontiers in which the freedom of movement is ensured take effect directly after the Treaty of Amsterdam enters into force, or will individual Member States be able to maintain existing border controls?

Does Article 14(3) mean that a Member State may maintain certain forms of border controls after the Council, acting by a qualified majority, has decided to end existing border controls?

Does Article 62(1) mean that controls on persons crossing internal borders must end no later than five years after the Treaty of Amsterdam enters into force, but also that border controls can continue for up to five years from that date?

Answer

The Commission has always believed that there is a link between the removal of controls on persons crossing internal borders and the implementation of a number of accompanying measures to guarantee a high level of security in the area without frontiers. This link was taken into account by the Commission in its 1995 proposals seeking to achieve the aim of removing controls on persons crossing internal borders.

The Treaty of Amsterdam confirms legally the link between freedom and security. In fact, the new Article 61 of the EC Treaty stipulates that the Council, within five years after the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, adopts measures aimed at ensuring the free movement of persons in accordance with Article 14, “in conjunction with directly related flanking measures’, and lists these measures.

With the exception of measures already approved on the basis of Article 100C of the current EC Treaty, in the course of a five‐year period, these measures will be taken unanimously.

The Commission recalls two protocols annexed to the Treaty of Amsterdam which are of importance in this context:

‐ the Protocol integrating the Schengen acquis into the framework of the European Union’: this acquis, according to which the Member States concerned commit themselves to the abolition of internal frontiers, will, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, be applied within the institutional and legal framework of the EU;

‐ the Protocol on the application of certain aspects of Article 7a of the Treaty establishing the European Community to the United Kingdom and to Ireland’, which gives these countries the right to exercise controls on persons at their frontiers with other Member States, and, vice versa, gives the other Member States the right to exercise controls on all persons coming from the United Kingdom or Ireland.

Question No 119 by John McCartin (H−0349/98)

Subject: Tariff free quota regime for herring

What discussions have taken place within the Commission and has the Commission made any decision on a proposal for the discontinuation of the present tariff free quota regime for herring imports for processing in the light of the current prognosis on EU herring supply in 1998 and forward years?

Answer

The TAC for herring varies slightly from one year to the next and this situation has, of course, repercussions for Community herring supply.

The autonomous quota system, for which quantities and duties are established annually, allows the processing industry"s supply to be regulated in accordance with the increase or reduction in TAC for herring.

Taking into account the increase in TAC for herring in 1998 over 1997, as well as the worrying market situation in certain Member States (Ireland in particular), the Commission has not proposed establishing an autonomous tariff quota in 1998 for herring intended for the processing industry. However, the Council has finally decided to establish an autonomous quota of 12 500 tonnes for this product for processing.
